Key technologies include decentralized identifiers (DIDs), verifiable credentials, healthcare wallets, and front-end development using Vuejs or React with a Java/JavaScript backend and SQL database. The expected outcome is a functional prototype demonstrating secure, patient-controlled health data management and contributions to the literature on SSI integration in software engineering.

3840.title: Safety evaluation of object detectors in autonomous vehicle scenarios
3840.summary: This project evaluates object detectors in autonomous vehicles from a safety perspective. It involves a literature review of safety metrics for object detection and trajectory planning, applying selected metrics to existing algorithms and datasets like nuScenes or CARLA. The project will experiment with algorithm variants and potentially define a benchmark for comparing object detectors based on safety. The expected outcome is a methodology for assessing autonomous vehicles from a safety viewpoint.

3842.title: Generative AI for modeling tasks in software and systems engineering
3842.summary: This project explores the application of Generative AI (GenAI), specifically Large Language Models (LLMs), to automate and simplify modeling tasks in software and systems engineering. It involves a literature review and practical application of open-source GenAI models to a specific modeling task, such as code generation from models, model generation from natural language, or model modification. The research aims to improve the efficiency and reduce errors in software and systems modeling using GenAI. Technologies used include Python, Git, and potentially UML/SysML.

3848.title: A shift from old-school to cutting-edge – redefined homecare services delivery platform
3848.summary: This project explores using decentralized technology, specifically a user-owned health wallet platform, to improve homecare services in Trondheim municipality. The research will involve stakeholder interviews, development of a proof-of-concept web and mobile application, and a mixed-methods evaluation comparing the decentralized approach to traditional systems. Key evaluation criteria include user-centric data ownership, data privacy and security, operational efficiency, cost-effectiveness, and user satisfaction levels. The expected outcome is a more efficient, transparent, and patient-centric homecare service model.

3849.title: Designing a next generation user identities platform using web 3.0 technologies
3849.summary: This project proposes developing a user-owned digital wallet platform leveraging Web 3.0 technologies like self-sovereign identity for secure storage and management of identity documents (diplomas, licenses). The platform will feature encryption, biometric authentication, and user-friendly interface for easy document access, sharing, and renewal reminders. The project involves stakeholder consultation, prototype development, pilot testing, and iterative refinement based on user feedback, aiming for wider adoption and integration with existing digital systems.

3850.title: Advancing Identity Security through AI
3850.summary: This project explores AI's role in enhancing identity security. It aims to analyze current identity verification methods and design an AI-powered system to improve accuracy and efficiency. The project will evaluate the system's performance, focusing on accuracy, false positives, and user satisfaction, to fortify personal information protection and prevent identity theft.

3854.title: Digital Forensics
3854.summary: This digital forensics project explores using writing style to identify author characteristics, detect plagiarism, and uncover social media misuse. It focuses on author profiling (age, gender, bot detection) and identification, and plagiarism detection. The expected outcome is a system capable of analyzing text to deduce author attributes and identify potential instances of plagiarism or misuse.

3855.title: Fighting Bias in Large Language Models
3855.summary: This project investigates and mitigates demographic biases in large language models, a critical area in current AI research. The project focuses on improving bias identification, quantification, and de-biasing methods. It aims to contribute to fair representation in language models by exploring unbiased datasets and refining learning algorithms. The expected outcome is a better understanding of bias and the development of effective techniques to reduce it in language models.

3856.title: Predicting Social Media Personalities, Values and Ethics
3856.summary: This project explores the relationship between social media activity and user personality, values, and ethics. It will investigate the application of models like Schwartz's values theory and Goldberg's Big 5 personality traits to social media text and networks. The goal is to predict user personalities based on their online behavior and social connections.

3859.title: Design and Evaluation: A digital tool to empower children to self-report their emotions and learning
3859.summary: This project focuses on developing and evaluating a digital tool for children to self-report their emotions and learning during design thinking activities. The project involves creating a web-based tool, potentially extending EmoForm, using technologies like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and Python. The tool's effectiveness will be evaluated through user studies in real-world settings, collecting and analyzing data to understand its impact. The expected outcome is a functional and usable digital tool and a comprehensive evaluation of its effectiveness in capturing children's emotional experiences during learning.

3861.title: Toolkit for Technologically Rich Education
3861.summary: This project aims to develop a digital toolkit to support K-12 students in technology-rich Design Thinking activities (Empathize, Ideate, Define, Prototype, Test). The toolkit will guide students through collaborative problem-solving and gather data on their performance. The project involves a literature review, iterative toolkit design (platform or website), data gathering/analysis, and user testing. Expected outcomes include a functional toolkit, insights into student learning processes, and an evaluation of the toolkit's efficacy. Required skills include software/interface design, JavaScript programming, and interest in user-centered research.

3875.title: Shared Situational Awareness through Role-based Workspaces
3875.summary: This project explores enhancing shared situational awareness in industrial operations by integrating Active Knowledge Models (AKM) and role-based workspaces with the OSDU data platform. The research involves extracting data and information objects from OSDU, creating and enhancing data elements using IRTV constructs within the AKM modeller. A key task is developing new meta-model capabilities supporting formal modeling standards like Archimate for OSDU integration. The expected outcomes are functional use cases demonstrating the approach and a meta-model for role-based workspaces within OSDU. This work is in collaboration with Equinor.

3876.title: Contextualising data on the OSDU data platform
3876.summary: This project explores contextualizing data within the OSDU data platform using Active Knowledge Models (AKM) and role-specific workspaces. It aims to improve dataset discovery and link analyses to source data, addressing challenges in the upstream oil and gas sector. The project involves literature review, AKM model creation, OSDU schema import, and exploration of smart contextualization algorithms. Expected outcomes include identifying datasets for specific roles/tasks and investigating how contextualized data can automate tasks, potentially enabling cross-industry knowledge transfer, in collaboration with Equinor.

3881.title: Git dashboard
3881.summary: This project aims to develop a Git dashboard for educational settings, providing instructors with an overview of student projects. The dashboard will aggregate data from Git via API and generate insights through static/dynamic code analysis. The goal is to enable instructors to efficiently monitor and compare project status and information, building upon previous related projects.

3882.title: System for vurdering av prosjekt og kode i en læringskontekst
3882.summary: This project focuses on developing a submission and feedback system for project and programming courses. It will explore functionalities such as code review, peer assessment of projects, automated testing, and the integration of generative AI. The system aims to improve learning through diverse feedback mechanisms, including instructor feedback, peer reviews, and automated analysis. Expected outcomes include a functional system capable of providing comprehensive feedback and potentially summarizing/quality-assuring peer assessments.

3883.title: Generativ kunstig intelligens i programmering
3883.summary: This project explores the use of generative AI in programming, focusing on its impact on learning and software development. Potential research areas include developing AI-powered chatbots for programming education, using AI to evaluate code against learning outcomes, and investigating AI's role in assessment. The expected outcome is a better understanding of how generative AI can be leveraged to improve programming education and software development processes.

3884.title: Læringsteknologi
3884.summary: This master's project explores learning technology, encompassing software and technological products that support learning and teaching. The project offers flexibility for student-selected tasks, either individually or in collaboration with faculty. Projects can be related to the Excited center for excellent education. Expected outcomes include advancements in understanding and application of learning technologies within educational settings.

3885.title: Species prediction models applied to vulnerability detection in software
3885.summary: This project explores applying species prediction models to software vulnerability detection. It aims to adapt models inspired by species accumulation curves to analyze the cumulative number of software vulnerabilities discovered over time. By using historical vulnerability data and factors like software complexity, the models will predict the rate of new vulnerability discoveries and estimate the total number of vulnerabilities. The expected outcome is to help software vendors and security researchers estimate the number of vulnerabilities and adapt bug hunting strategies.

3901.title: XR - Augmented reality tools for serious gaming or medical applications
3901.summary: This project explores the design of extended reality (XR) tools for serious games and medical applications. Potential research areas include AI and LLMs for serious games, AI-driven content generation in XR, bronchoscopy training and planning, and echocardiography surgical planning. The expected outcome is functional XR applications that leverage AI and XR technologies to enhance learning, training, and surgical planning in medical and gaming contexts.

3910.title: City learning
3910.summary: This project explores how cities can learn and evolve to align with transformations like energy transitions and digitalization. Building on an existing theoretical model for city learning, the project aims to develop a practical tool (e.g., a card set or game) to support city stakeholders in their learning and evolution processes. The methodology includes reviewing existing solutions, iteratively designing and developing the tool, and validating its effectiveness. The expected outcome is a validated tool that cities can use to facilitate continuous learning and adaptation.

3911.title: Digital Technologies for “placemaking” and “placekeeping”
3911.summary: This project explores how digital technologies can facilitate "placemaking" and "placekeeping" to improve public spaces and community wellbeing. It aims to identify and prototype a digital solution, potentially using Augmented Reality or digital storytelling, to foster emotional connections to places through shared experiences. The research will involve literature review, iterative design, and participatory methods with end-users to validate the solution's effectiveness in creating and maintaining meaningful places.

3912.title: Crowdsourcing using Geographical Information Systems
3912.summary: This project proposes developing a crowdsourcing GIS platform to enhance place knowledge through shared stories and experiences. It will leverage open-source GIS and explore the application of Large Language Models (LLMs) for content analysis. The project includes a literature review, prototype development, LLM integration, and validation. Expected outcomes include a functional prototype and insights into using LLMs to analyze crowdsourced geographical narratives, contributing to a deeper understanding of place.

3914.title: Smart Urban Data Collection for Health and Well-being
3914.summary: This project investigates urban health and well-being using mobile phone and smartwatch data collection. It combines quantitative data with individual perceptions gathered in outdoor and public spaces. The research involves literature review, study design, data collection and analysis, and identifying design implications. The expected outcome is a comprehensive understanding of individual well-being in urban environments, contributing to the NTNU SWELL sustainability project.

3917.title: Flexible data visualization in a VR environment to aid the assessment of visuospatial neglect using eye tracking
3917.summary: This project aims to enhance visuospatial neglect assessment using VR and eye-tracking. It involves developing flexible data visualization tools within a custom VR environment. The project will use Python to generate gaze data plots from VR-collected data and display them within the VR environment. The project will classify gaze data into fixations and saccades, and present relevant statistical information in an easily understandable format for clinicians. This work is in collaboration with the Department of Acquired Brain Injury, St. Olav's Hospital.

3918.title: Use of honeypots for understanding attacker methodologies in n-day vulnerable software
3918.summary: This project investigates honeypots simulating n-day vulnerable software to understand attacker methodologies and improve network security. A systematic literature review will identify research gaps, focusing on differentiating automated vs. manual attacks, honeypot realism and security, deployment strategies, threat intelligence, and anti-honeypot techniques. The expected outcome is a deeper understanding of honeypot effectiveness in detecting and mitigating cyber threats, informing better security operations.

3920.title: Generative AI for Meta Data Inference (with DNB)
3920.summary: This project focuses on using generative AI to infer missing metadata in large document archives, specifically for DNB. The project involves building an NLP pipeline to process documents, applying machine learning methods to estimate missing metadata (e.g., document type, product references), and creating a reference dataset. Expected outcomes include a functional system for metadata inference and a demonstration of its effectiveness on DNB's document archive. The student may have the opportunity to intern at DNB.

3923.title: Generative AI for Customer Relationship Management (with Sparebank 1 SMN)
3923.summary: This project explores the application of Generative AI, specifically Large Language Models (LLMs), to enhance Customer Relationship Management at Sparebank 1 SMN. The research aims to compare the performance of LLMs against traditional machine learning models in categorizing customer messages (emails and chats in Norwegian). The project will utilize a dataset of over 560,000 messages provided by Sparebank 1 SMN. The expected outcome is to determine if LLMs can improve the reliability of message categorization, potentially leading to improved customer service.

3925.title: Topological Methods for Condition Monitoring in Heavy Asset Industries (with Cognite)
3925.summary: This project explores Topological Data Analysis (TDA) for condition monitoring in heavy industries, aiming to improve failure prediction in assets like wind turbines and oil & gas equipment. The research will apply persistent homology and related topological methods to industrial datasets provided by Cognite, potentially developing new topology-based methods. Expected outcomes include novel data pipelines for predicting equipment failure and comparison with deep learning approaches, leveraging Python programming and advanced mathematical concepts.

3931.title: EduWallet: A Blockchain-Enabled Digital Wallet for Managing University Course Credits
3931.summary: EduWallet aims to transform university credit management using blockchain technology. It integrates with Blackboard and Inspera APIs for real-time credit updates and uses smart contracts for secure enrollment and credit transfer. The system offers real-time verification of academic records, token-based incentives for achievements, and an analytics dashboard for students. Expected outcomes include enhanced security, efficiency, and transferability of course credits, improving student mobility and academic record management.

3933.title: Zero Emission Farm – digital game design and development
3933.summary: This project focuses on designing and developing a digital game to promote awareness and knowledge about zero-emission farms and reducing greenhouse gas emissions in agriculture. The project will involve literature review, iterative game design, and validation. It will be conducted in collaboration with Mære Agricultural School and build upon their existing Climate Calculator. The expected outcome is a functional game that effectively educates users about sustainable farming practices.

3934.title: Personalized rehabilitation video generation using sensor data and Generative AI
3934.summary: This project explores personalized rehabilitation video generation using sensor data and Generative AI. It aims to create tailored training videos based on patient-specific exercises captured via sensors. The research focuses on using sensor data to create avatar videos and training a generative AI model to transform these avatars into personalized training videos. Expected outcomes include a system capable of automatically generating customized rehabilitation content.

3935.title: AI-based Fair Recruitment Systems
3935.summary: This project investigates fair decision-making in AI-based hiring systems, focusing on the automated extraction of feature importance weights from recruitment data. It aims to compare these automatically derived weights with human-provided weights to ensure objectivity and consistency. The research will utilize machine learning techniques, potentially including K-Nearest Neighbors, and regression evaluation metrics (MAE, MSE, RMSE). Expected outcomes include insights into aligning AI decisions with human values in hiring processes and contributing to the BIAS project's goal of mitigating bias in AI.

3936.title: Evaluating quantizations of large language models on edge systems
3936.summary: This project evaluates the effectiveness of different quantization methods for large language models (LLMs) on edge systems. It focuses on assessing the trade-offs between quantization overhead, accuracy, and responsiveness. The research will involve implementing and testing various quantization techniques on a target edge platform like Nvidia Jetson TX2. The expected outcome is a comparative analysis of quantization methods, providing insights into their suitability for deploying LLMs on resource-constrained edge devices.

3937.title: On-device personalization of large language models on edge devices
3937.summary: This project explores on-device personalization of large language models (LLMs) for edge systems, aiming to reduce model complexity and latency while potentially improving accuracy. The research focuses on developing a low-overhead, hardware-aware personalization method that operates entirely on edge devices, leveraging their limited computational resources. The expected outcome is an efficient on-device personalization technique suitable for resource-constrained edge environments.

3939.title: Smart Desks
3939.summary: This project explores the creation of "smart" or "context-aware" desks to facilitate shared office space. It involves researching existing literature, designing and implementing IoT-based prototypes with accompanying software, and conducting user tests to evaluate the solution. The expected outcome is a functional prototype and insights into optimizing desk sharing through technology.

3942.title: Cool AI
3942.summary: This project focuses on exploring a "cool" and difficult problem or method within the field of Artificial Intelligence. The specific research area and technologies will be determined based on the chosen problem. The expected outcome is a novel contribution to AI, demonstrating a solution to the selected challenge.

3945.title: Hybrid Vector Search in High-Dimensional Space
3945.summary: This project explores hybrid vector search in high-dimensional spaces, aiming to improve and extend existing solutions from the 2024 SIGMOD Programming Contest. The research focuses on building an index that efficiently finds approximate k-nearest neighbors based on vector similarity while satisfying constraints on non-vector attributes. The project will leverage existing codebases from top-performing teams as baselines and investigate more sophisticated indexing techniques. Expected outcomes include enhanced query performance, support for diverse attribute types, and handling of various query types within strict time constraints.

3946.title: Enhancing Domain-Specific Retrieval-Augmented Generation: Challenges and Solutions for Precise Textual Embeddings and Citations
3946.summary: This project focuses on enhancing domain-specific Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) by addressing challenges in creating precise textual embeddings and citations. It aims to improve algorithms for processing domain-specific language to generate robust embedding vectors. The research also refines retrieval mechanisms and citation algorithms to increase the accuracy and relevance of citations in generated texts. The expected outcome is to advance RAG techniques through algorithmic enhancements and empirical testing, improving the reliability and verifiability of generated content.

3947.title: Multimodal Personality Prediction
3947.summary: This project explores multimodal personality prediction using machine learning. It aims to develop algorithms, specifically deep neural networks, to analyze asynchronous video interviews and online profiles (e.g., LinkedIn) to predict personality traits based on the Big Five model. The expected outcome is a system that can infer personality from multimodal data, potentially improving recruitment processes by offering an alternative to traditional questionnaires.

3949.title: E-Assessment in Higher Education with the Support of Large Language Models
3949.summary: This project evaluates the performance of LLMs (ChatGPT, Palm, LLaMA, Mistral) in e-assessment. It involves training LLMs on course content, using prompt engineering to generate question papers with varying difficulty levels and formats. The project assesses the LLMs' ability to score student responses and provide descriptive feedback. The goal is to determine the capabilities of different foundational models in e-assessment and the impact of fine-tuning. The project will be implemented in Python, requiring skills in machine learning, deep learning, and prompt engineering.

3950.title: Bloom's learning outcomes classification: comparative analysis of different LLMs potential
3950.summary: This project investigates the potential of Large Language Models (LLMs) for classifying course learning objectives according to Bloom's Taxonomy (remember, understand, apply, analyze, evaluate, create). It aims to design a model to classify course descriptions and learning objectives into Bloom's levels and compare its performance against existing LLMs. The project utilizes Python, machine learning, deep learning, and prompt engineering. The expected outcome is a comparative analysis of LLMs' effectiveness in Bloom's Taxonomy classification.

3955.title: Cross-Lingual Sentence Simplification with Large Language Models
3955.summary: This project explores cross-lingual sentence simplification using Large Language Models (LLMs). It aims to simplify complex sentences in one language into simpler sentences in another, preserving meaning. The project will involve fine-tuning LLMs on monolingual simplification datasets and parallel corpora with one-to-many and many-to-one sentence alignments. Evaluation will be performed using NorLLM and TrustLLM models, benchmarking against state-of-the-art approaches. The expected outcome is a cross-lingual sentence simplification system leveraging LLMs.

3957.title: Solving Cryptic Crosswords with Large Language Models
3957.summary: This project explores the use of Large Language Models (LLMs) for solving cryptic crosswords, a challenging reasoning task where current LLMs achieve significantly lower accuracy than humans. The project aims to refine existing methods by benchmarking NorwAI's LLMs against state-of-the-art models. A secondary goal involves creating datasets for Norwegian cryptic crosswords, potentially through synthetic generation and collaboration with rights holders.

3958.title: Comparing Synthetic to Real Alignment Data
3958.summary: This project investigates the effectiveness of synthetic data versus real data for aligning Norwegian Large Language Models (LLMs), addressing data scarcity challenges. It will compare synthetic and real data using models from the TrustLLM and NorLLM projects. The research will involve both qualitative and quantitative evaluations to determine if synthetic data can compensate for a lack of real alignment data, as suggested by the RAND corporation. The project aims to provide insights into the viability of synthetic data for LLM alignment in low-resource languages.

3959.title: Uncertainty Quantification for Language Models in Safety-Critical Systems
3959.summary: This project investigates Uncertainty Quantification (UQ) for Language Models (LMs) in safety-critical systems. It addresses the need for reliable LMs by quantifying uncertainties from data limitations and model architecture. The project involves literature review, implementation, and testing of LMs (e.g., deep learning, Tsetlin Machines) and UQ methods on NLP benchmark datasets. Expected outcomes include insights into UQ techniques, addressing challenges like hallucination and interpretability, and contributing to the application of UQ in LMs. The project is in collaboration with DNV, a risk management and assurance company.

3962.title: Recognizing meta-data on car tires
3962.summary: This project aims to automate car tire meta-data extraction, profile depth estimation, and damage detection using computer vision. Leveraging a large image dataset of tires with manually collected meta-data, the student will develop computer vision models to predict tire size, manufacturer, profile depth, and identify damages. The expected outcome is an automated system that reduces manual effort in tire maintenance, supported by Trønderdekk AS.

3963.title: Effects of fully immersive VR games for people with intellectual disability
3963.summary: This project investigates the effects of fully immersive VR games on individuals with intellectual disabilities. Focusing on their learning through repetition, the research explores VR's potential in teaching various tasks. The study aims to provide insights into the effects and usage of VR for this specific group, addressing the challenges posed by their diverse functioning levels. The expected outcome is a better understanding of how VR can support learning and development in individuals with intellectual disabilities.

3965.title: Processing and analysing ice data
3965.summary: This project focuses on processing and analyzing ice data, specifically satellite data, for shipping in the Arctic and Baltic Sea regions. It aims to identify needs for satellite data, assess existing services and products, and analyze how the data is currently used. The research is part of a larger ESA/EC-financed project exploring Earth Observation data applications in maritime, oil & gas, and raw material extraction. Expected outcomes include insights into satellite data utilization and potential improvements for Arctic and Baltic Sea shipping.

3970.title: Applying LLM technologies to Parallel Computing
3970.summary: This project explores the application of Large Language Models (LLMs) to enhance parallel computing. It investigates how LLMs can assist in optimizing parallel code and potentially serve as a "co-pilot" for parallel programming, including educational applications. The project involves a literature survey and aims to identify specific areas where AI can advance parallel programming. Expected outcomes include insights into the utility of LLMs in parallel computing and potential tools or methodologies for improved parallel programming workflows.

3979.title: Mestringslæring i Intro programmering
3979.summary: This project investigates mastery learning in introductory programming using a mixed-methods approach. It will study a teaching intervention employing mastery learning principles. The research aims to understand the impact of this approach on student learning outcomes in introductory programming.

3980.title: FlexEEG decoding of hand movement intention
3980.summary: This project aims to decode hand movement intentions from low-density EEG signals using source reconstruction and machine/deep learning algorithms. EEG data will be recorded from participants, analyzed, and used to build offline/online classifiers. The decoded movements will be implemented in software games, with the goal of developing wearable EEG solutions for neurorehabilitation. Collaboration with Marta Molinas at the cybernetics department will support the project.

3982.title: Developing an autofocus for 3D shape matching algorithms
3982.summary: This project aims to develop an "autofocus" algorithm for 3D shape matching, automating the selection of the scale parameter crucial for comparing 3D surfaces. The research will focus on ensuring consistent scale estimation between corresponding points on similar surfaces, even with alterations. The expected outcome is an algorithm that dynamically adjusts the scale parameter, improving the accuracy and robustness of 3D shape matching algorithms used in applications like robotic navigation.

3985.title: Partial encryption of video
3985.summary: This project proposes a method for partial video encryption to protect privacy in surveillance footage. The research will focus on identifying and encrypting specific areas like faces or license plates within a video stream, using existing object recognition technology. The project aims to integrate encrypted data into the video stream without corrupting it, ensuring compatibility with standard video players. Modified Huffman coding may be used. The expected outcome is a functional filter that partially encrypts video, preserves video quality, and maintains playability, along with performance analysis regarding time consumption and compression ratio.

3986.title: AI and Game based learning (multiple projects)
3986.summary: This project focuses on developing an AI-driven system to enhance math learning through educational games. It addresses the "cold start problem" by detecting difficult moments for students using wearable sensors and providing targeted support. The project involves designing and implementing a feedback tool, conducting usability studies, evaluating system effectiveness through larger user studies, and analyzing collected data. The ideal candidate should have a background in system design, basic machine learning, and strong programming skills in Python/Java.

3987.title: Enhancing Online Laboratory Simulations Through AI-Powered Learning Analytics
3987.summary: This project develops AI-based analytics models to improve online laboratory simulations, particularly in STEM. It tracks learner interactions within Articulate Storyline 360 simulations to provide insights into engagement, skill acquisition, and performance. The goal is to inform real-time interventions and instructional design, ultimately enhancing student outcomes.

3988.title: Integrating AI Chatbots into Articulate Storyline 360 for Scaffolding Online Learning
3988.summary: This project explores integrating AI chatbots into Articulate Storyline 360 simulations to provide real-time learning scaffolding. The research will analyze the chatbots' effectiveness in addressing learner challenges and improving learning outcomes by analyzing learner interactions. The expected outcome is a better understanding of how conversational AI can personalize and enhance online learning.

3989.title: Evaluating the Role of Gamified Simulations in Enhancing Learner Motivation and Retention
3989.summary: This project explores gamified simulations built in Articulate Storyline 360 to boost learner motivation and retention. It integrates AI for adaptive game mechanics and performance tracking to personalize the learning experience. The research will evaluate the impact of these simulations on learner motivation, engagement, and retention rates, aiming to improve online education through deeper learning.

3990.title: Smidig transformasjon
3990.summary: This project explores the challenges of "agile transformation" in organizations, moving beyond software development to broader organizational adoption. It will begin with a literature review of agile transformation within system development, information systems, and change management. A potential extension involves an empirical study of organizations undergoing agile transformations, potentially leveraging data from the Agile 2.0 research project. The research aims to understand and address resistance to organizational change and difficulties in adapting agile methodologies across diverse organizational functions.

3991.title: Teamwork in software development
3991.summary: This project proposes a literature review of teamwork research within software development, particularly focusing on agile and distributed teams. It aims to identify factors influencing team effectiveness based on existing team performance models and empirical studies. The expected outcome is a comprehensive overview of current research, potentially leading to an empirical study in a master's thesis to further investigate these factors.

3992.title: Customized Master Projects in Basic Machine Learning Research
3992.summary: This master's project focuses on foundational machine learning research, offering students customized thesis topics aligned with their interests. Potential areas include algorithm development (supervised, unsupervised, reinforcement learning), theoretical investigations, model robustness, explainability, fairness, and optimization. Students will work alongside experienced researchers, gaining hands-on experience in tackling open ML problems. Example topics include recurrent self-attention, next-token prediction, image generation quality quantification, and self-supervised pretraining for tabular data. The project aims to contribute to cutting-edge advancements in machine learning.

3993.title: Scaling algorithms for databases
3993.summary: This project investigates hashing algorithms for scalable, distributed databases, building upon previous theoretical work. The research will focus on practical implementation and evaluation of various hashing algorithms to determine their suitability for database scaling. The expected outcome is a comparative analysis of hashing algorithms, identifying the most effective options for enhancing the scalability of distributed databases.

3994.title: XAI og bakdører i maskinlæringsmodeller
3994.summary: This project explores backdoors in machine learning models, replicating and extending existing research on planting backdoors, potentially using techniques from Explainable AI (XAI) to detect them. The research will investigate alternative methods for embedding backdoors. The project requires strong programming skills, an interest in mathematics and cryptography, and collaboration with students from the Department of Mathematical Sciences. Expected outcomes include understanding relevant techniques, assessing backdoor detectability, and exploring novel backdoor embedding methods.

3995.title: Graph compression and indexing
3995.summary: This project explores graph compression and indexing techniques for managing and extracting information from large graphs, such as web graphs, social networks, and genomic sequences. It focuses on designing compact data structures to address the limitations of traditional methods when handling massive datasets with redundancy. The research aims to develop efficient graph indexing methods, particularly for reachability queries, to enable faster data access and search in applications like bioinformatics and social science.

3996.title: MySQL related projects 2025
3996.summary: This master's project focuses on implementation and evaluation within MySQL, in cooperation with MySQL Engineering at Oracle Trondheim. Specific topics will be determined through discussion. The project requires strong programming skills, an interest in algorithms, and prior knowledge from courses like TDT4150. The expected outcome is a functional implementation and evaluation of a chosen MySQL-related feature or optimization.

3997.title: VIRTUAL DEVICES ACROSS OPERATING SYSTEMS
3997.summary: This project explores the creation of virtual camera and microphone devices compatible across Linux, macOS, and Android operating systems. Utilizing Python and C/C++, the research aims to develop applications for real-time voice and facial characteristic modifications. The expected outcome is a functional virtual device implementation and demonstration of its capabilities through novel applications.

3998.title: RECONSTRUCTION OF NIDAROSDOMEN BASED ON GAUSSIAN PRIMITIVES
3998.summary: This project aims to reconstruct a 3D Gaussian representation of the interior of Nidaros Cathedral from a large photographic dataset. Using Gaussian Splatting techniques, the project will generate novel views and walkthroughs of the cathedral. The project requires knowledge of Python and C/C++, and familiarity with visual computing and graphics visualization concepts.

3999.title: FACIAL DATA PROCESSING USING ZOOM SDK
3999.summary: This project explores facial data processing using the Zoom SDK. It involves developing facial processing tools utilizing raw image data from the Zoom platform. The project requires proficiency in Linux, Python, and C/C++, along with knowledge of visual computing fundamentals and graphics visualization. The expected outcome is a set of functional facial processing tools integrated with the Zoom SDK.

4000.title: VISUALIZATION LIBRARIES IN PYTHON
4000.summary: This project compares five Python visualization libraries. It requires Python knowledge and familiarity with visual computing or graphics visualization concepts. The project will define a specific task to evaluate and contrast the libraries' performance and capabilities. The expected outcome is a comparative analysis of the libraries, highlighting their strengths and weaknesses for the chosen task.

4003.title: On the relation between software engineering and AI in Norway
4003.summary: This empirical software engineering project investigates the relationship between software engineering practices and AI adoption in Norway. It will analyze data from TDT4290 projects, conduct literature reviews, interview customers and students, and analyze reports and software. The expected outcome is a comprehensive understanding of current trends and practices in developing AI-intensive systems within the Norwegian context.

4004.title: Customized Query Execution Plans in Graph Databases
4004.summary: This project aims to develop a system for injecting custom query execution plans and cardinalities into property graph databases like Kùzu or Neo4j. Building upon the concept of PgCuckoo for relational databases, the research will design and implement a solution that allows external optimizers to influence query planning within graph databases. The expected outcome is a tool that facilitates experimentation and research on query optimization strategies in graph database systems.

4005.title: Locality of Access in Graph Databases
4005.summary: This project investigates graph ordering schemes to improve data locality for graph queries, focusing on minimizing cache misses in scenarios where only a portion of the graph is accessed. It aims to implement and evaluate existing and potentially new graph ordering techniques, particularly at the disk level, using a benchmark based on real graph query workloads. The project may utilize graph database systems like Kùzu and requires knowledge of database internals and C/C++ programming. Expected outcomes include a comparative analysis of graph ordering schemes and insights into their effectiveness for various query types.

4006.title: Exploration of GraphRAG-extracted Knowledge Graphs
4006.summary: This project explores knowledge graphs extracted by GraphRAG, a structured RAG approach, to evaluate their quality and utility beyond question answering. The research aims to enhance understanding of GraphRAG's reasoning capabilities by developing a tool for efficient knowledge graph exploration, potentially using a graph database. The expected outcome is a deeper insight into the value of GraphRAG-extracted knowledge graphs for downstream tasks.

4007.title: Evaluation of Streaming Graph Processing Frameworks
4007.summary: This project evaluates existing streaming graph processing frameworks to address the gap in research compared to static graph processing. The goal is to design a prototype processing pipeline for efficient analytics on real-world streaming graphs. The project requires a basic understanding of graph theory, algorithms, and data analytics technologies. The expected outcome is a functional prototype and an evaluation of current streaming graph processing frameworks.

4008.title: Bærekraftsrapportering (sustainability reporting)
4008.summary: This master's project investigates the challenges and solutions for collecting, processing, and reporting sustainability data to meet the EU's Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) requirements, focusing on scope 3 emissions. In collaboration with Aneo AS, the project will address the under-specification of "sustainability," relevant data identification, data compilation methods, and target audience relevance. The research aims to provide insights into how companies can effectively integrate sustainability into their reporting practices.

4009.title: Digitalisering i olje og gass - IoT
4009.summary: This project explores the role of IoT and digitalization in the oil and gas industry, specifically focusing on unmanned subsea facilities. It addresses the challenge of unreliable sensor data (temperature, pressure, seismicity, etc.) used in exploration, drilling, logging, and production. The research aims to determine how new IT tools can enable better decision-making despite sensor uncertainty and limited lifespan in deep-sea environments. The expected outcome is a better understanding of how to leverage sensor data effectively in remote oil and gas operations.

4010.title: Health information systems in developing countries
4010.summary: This project investigates health information systems in developing countries, focusing on the DHIS2 initiative, an open-source platform enhancing health service reporting. Utilizing mobile technologies, the research involves empirical fieldwork in Africa or Asia to identify requirements for selected DHIS2 services. The goal is to contribute to the implementation and evolution of DHIS2 software, improving healthcare delivery in resource-limited settings. Collaboration with the University of Oslo's DHIS2 team is a key component.

4011.title: Samarbeide og kommunikasjon i helsesektoren
4011.summary: This project investigates challenges in healthcare collaboration due to fragmented information systems hindering seamless patient care across different healthcare providers. It aims to analyze the implementation of a digital service within the healthcare sector, employing empirical methods like observation, interviews, and system usage logging to gather requirements. The project will operationalize these requirements into recommended functionalities, potentially including a prototype, to improve distributed workflow support and enhance healthcare collaboration.

4012.title: Compilers for Approximate Computing
4012.summary: This project explores compiler techniques for approximate computing, specifically precision tuning. It aims to optimize performance metrics like speed and energy consumption by modifying data types (e.g., reducing bit precision, using fixed-point numbers). The project involves code analysis, transformations, and verification using C/C++, CMake, and potentially LLVM-IR or MLIR. Expected outcomes include novel compiler optimizations for approximate computing and collaboration with international research teams.

4013.title: Chop my Chip! Dynamic Compilation Targets for Hardware-Software Codesign
4013.summary: This project explores dynamic compilation targets within the LLVM compiler for hardware-software codesign using RISC-V. The goal is to enable rapid exploration of custom ISA extensions for domain-specific accelerators (e.g., autonomous driving, cryptography). The project aims to allow the compiler to recompile programs for various ISA variations and assess performance impact. It requires C/C++ programming, familiarity with CMake, Git, and LLVM, and involves collaboration with the University of Bologna and Politecnico di Milano.

4014.title: Human-Centered AI for Responsible Digital Transformation
4014.summary: This project explores human-centered AI within digital transformation, focusing on aligning AI systems with human values and societal well-being while achieving business value. Research can be tailored to organizational strategy, user interaction, technical design, or policy-making within sectors like healthcare or education, and technologies like machine learning or IoT. Methods include quantitative surveys, qualitative interviews, case studies, or design science. Expected outcomes include insights into stakeholder engagement, policy implications, and innovative technical designs for responsible AI implementation.

4015.title: Unlocking Insights from Video Content – A Large Language Model Approach
4015.summary: This project explores using Large Language Models (LLMs) to analyze spoken content from YouTube videos. It involves building a system to automatically retrieve and process transcripts from videos and playlists using the YouTube API. The system will employ LLMs for topic extraction, summarization, and trend visualization, presented through a user-friendly interface. A user study will evaluate the system's effectiveness. The expected outcome is a tool that provides meaningful insights from large amounts of video content.

4017.title: Extending hybrid vector search (multiple projects)
4017.summary: This project explores extensions to hybrid vector search, combining vector similarity search with additional constraints and database operations. Potential research areas include combining vector search with database joins, streaming hybrid vector search, GPU-enhanced extensions, learned indexes, and queries on vector-trajectory objects. The project involves developing and implementing algorithms/indexes in C++ and evaluating them on large datasets using pre-trained embeddings. Expected outcomes are novel algorithms and indexes for improved hybrid vector search performance.

4018.title: Exploring Meta-Learning Strategies for Few-Shot Graph Learning Tasks
4018.summary: This project explores meta-learning strategies for few-shot graph learning using Graph Neural Networks (GNNs). It aims to improve generalization in GNNs with limited labeled data by transferring knowledge across different graph learning tasks. The research involves a literature review, framework analysis, implementation of baseline methods, and the development of novel meta-learning algorithms tailored for graph data. Expected outcomes include a comprehensive analysis of meta-learning for graphs, novel algorithms, visualization tools for meta-knowledge transfer, and guidelines for applying these techniques to real-world problems.

4019.title: Examining Adaptation Shifting in Graph Domain Adaptation Tasks
4019.summary: This project investigates adaptation shifting in Graph Domain Adaptation (GDA) using adaptation-based methods. It aims to characterize domain shifts in graph data, evaluate existing GDA methods, and develop metrics/visualizations for measuring these shifts. The project involves literature review, dataset selection, implementation of state-of-the-art methods, and potentially novel algorithm development. Expected outcomes include a comprehensive analysis of adaptation shifts, new metrics for domain shift measurement, experimental insights on shift effects, and guidelines for selecting appropriate GDA methods.

4021.title: How well do deep learning 3D object classification methods work with large datasets?
4021.summary: This project investigates the performance of deep learning methods for 3D object classification on large datasets. It aims to evaluate state-of-the-art methods, previously benchmarked on Modelnet40 and ScanObjectNN, using larger, more recently available datasets. The goal is to provide a more robust comparison of these methods and determine their effectiveness when dealing with significantly increased data volumes, potentially revealing more substantial performance differences.

4022.title: Anomaly detection using foundational time-series models
4022.summary: This project explores anomaly detection in time series data using foundational time-series models like Lag-Llama and TimesFM. The research aims to leverage the zero and few-shot capabilities of these models to develop an anomaly detection system applicable to real-world data. The project involves understanding the state-of-the-art anomaly detection techniques and then implementing and testing the new system. The expected outcome is a zero or few-shot anomaly detection system validated on real-life datasets.

4023.title: Probabilistic models for Generative AI
4023.summary: This project explores probabilistic models for generative AI, focusing on diffusion models and related approaches like Bayesian flow networks. The project can be tailored to the student's interests, encompassing theoretical analysis, comparative studies (e.g., diffusion models vs. GANs/VAEs), or practical applications on a dataset of interest. The expected outcome is a deeper understanding of generative AI models and their potential through either theoretical advancements, empirical comparisons, or practical implementations.

4024.title: [Collaboration with Maritime Robotics] Efficient Vision Transformers for Real-Time Object Segmentation and Deployment on NVIDIA AGX Orin
4024.summary: This project explores efficient Vision Transformers (ViTs) for real-time object segmentation on the NVIDIA AGX Orin, in collaboration with Maritime Robotics. It focuses on transformer-specific optimizations like sparse attention, token reduction, and mixed-precision quantization to improve speed, power efficiency, and accuracy. The research will benchmark optimized ViT models against baseline implementations and CNN-based methods, aiming for seamless integration into the SeaSight system. Expected outcomes include optimized ViT implementations for real-time inference and a comparative framework for ViT and CNN deployment in maritime surveillance.

4025.title: [Collaboration with Maritime Robotics] Optimising RTMDet / RTMDet-Ins on NVIDIA AGX Orin
4025.summary: This project focuses on optimizing the RTMDet object detection model for real-time performance on the NVIDIA AGX Orin platform, targeting Maritime Robotics' SeaSight pipeline. It will explore techniques like model quantization, pruning, and GPU/DLA offloading using TensorRT and CUDA. The goal is to achieve real-time inference with minimal energy consumption, integrating the optimized model into SeaSight to enhance situational awareness for USV operators. Expected outcomes include an optimized RTMDet implementation and a set of tailored optimization techniques for the Orin platform.

4026.title: Diversity Equity and Inclusion (DEI) in software development
4026.summary: This project investigates Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) practices within Norwegian software development. Using empirical software engineering methods, the research will explore how companies incorporate diversity into their organizations and projects. Data will be collected through interviews, analysis of course materials, report/software analysis, and workshops with companies and students. The goal is to understand the impact of diversity on software development teams and to develop guidelines for disclosing diversity in software development processes.

4027.title: Employee-driven digital transformation
4027.summary: This research investigates employee participation in digital transformation, analyzing successful and failed attempts to identify challenges and best practices. It employs empirical qualitative research methods to analyze past research and conduct studies in organizations undergoing digital transformation. The expected outcome is a set of recommendations for improving employee involvement in future digitalization initiatives. The research will be conducted in Norwegian, with the thesis potentially written in English.

4028.title: Qualitative study of Microsoft Copilot use by computing students
4028.summary: This project investigates how computing students at NTNU use Microsoft Copilot and its impact on their learning. The research employs a qualitative case study approach, utilizing observations, interviews, and archival data collection. The goal is to understand the practices of students using Copilot through qualitative data analysis. Expected outcomes include a rich understanding of Copilot usage patterns and their effects on student learning in a computing context.

4029.title: [ExerGames] Exercise Bike Game Development and User Evaluation 2025/2026
4029.summary: This project focuses on developing exergame concepts using an exercise bike as a primary game controller, supplemented by traditional button inputs. The goal is to create an engaging and motivating experience that promotes physical activity. The project involves researching existing exergames, designing and implementing a prototype in Unity, and evaluating its impact on enjoyment, motivation, and exercise through user testing. The expected outcome is a functional exergame prototype and an evaluation of its effectiveness.

4030.title: [ExerGames] Play to get fit 2025/2026
4030.summary: This project explores exergames, aiming to balance engaging gameplay with effective physical activity. It involves researching game-based motivation, designing and implementing a prototype, and evaluating its effectiveness. The expected outcome is an exergame prototype and insights into creating engaging and beneficial fitness games.

4031.title: [BitPet]  AI Integration in a Location-Based AR Game for Socialization and Physical Activity (2025/2026)
4031.summary: This project investigates AI integration in BitPet, a location-based AR game, to boost player engagement, socialization, and physical activity. The research involves studying AR, location-based technologies, and AI in gaming. Development focuses on implementing AI-driven features using Unity, with support from BitPet developers. Real-user testing will evaluate the effectiveness of AI enhancements. The expected outcome is an enhanced AR game experience through AI, validated by user feedback.

4032.title: [BitPet]  Empirical Study on the Physical and Social Health Effects of Playing BitPet (2025/2026)
4032.summary: This project investigates the physical and social health impacts of BitPet, a location-based AR game promoting activity and social interaction. The research will employ questionnaires, interviews, observations, and in-game data analysis to assess BitPet's influence on physical and social activity, usability, and player experience. Expected outcomes include an evaluation of BitPet's health benefits, identification of key game elements, design guidelines for similar games, and potential extensions to exergaming theories.

4033.title: A computer game to teach EU AI Act for the healthcare domain users
4033.summary: This project explores the design and development of an educational computer game to teach the EU AI Act to healthcare professionals. Applying the design science research method, the project will create a game prototype and a methodology for designing such games. The game will be piloted and evaluated by healthcare stakeholders. Expected outcomes include a functional game prototype and a documented methodology for creating educational games on complex regulations like the EU AI Act.

4034.title: Agentic AI security vulnerabilities identification and mitigation
4034.summary: This project investigates security vulnerabilities in Agentic AI systems, which utilize LLMs and other agents for complex tasks. The research will employ systematic literature reviews and design science to identify vulnerabilities and develop mitigation strategies. Expected outcomes include approaches and prototypes for identifying and mitigating Agentic AI risks, requiring strong coding skills and knowledge in AI and cybersecurity.

4035.title: Implementing time-proportional profiling for the XiangShan core
4035.summary: This project focuses on implementing and evaluating a Time-proportional Instruction Profiler (TIP) on the XiangShan RISC-V core, an open-source high-performance out-of-order processor. Building upon existing work, the project aims to integrate a proof-of-concept TIP implementation with XiangShan running on FPGAs. The expected outcomes include evaluating TIP on XiangShan and potentially implementing a TEA performance event analyzer or conducting a detailed performance comparison between XiangShan and Berkeley's BOOM core.

4036.title: Efficient acceleration of Edge AI workloads
4036.summary: This project explores efficient acceleration of Edge AI workloads on battery-less IoT devices using FPGA accelerators. The research focuses on optimizing FPGA utilization in intermittent computing scenarios, addressing challenges posed by frequent power failures in energy harvesting IoT nodes. The expected outcome is a strategy for effectively using FPGAs to enable energy-efficient Edge AI inference on resource-constrained, intermittently powered IoT platforms.

4037.title: An open simulation infrastructure for mobile GPUs for graphics
4037.summary: This project aims to develop an open-source simulation infrastructure for mobile GPUs, extending the Vulkan-Sim framework to support a broader range of graphics workloads beyond raytracing. The goal is to create a collaborative platform for Arm Trondheim and NTNU's CAL. The project involves exploring the design space of mobile GPUs to identify optimal configurations. Expected outcomes include a versatile simulation tool and insights into mobile GPU architecture.

4038.title: Exploring the architectural fidelity of CPU microarchitecture simulators
4038.summary: This project investigates the architectural fidelity of the ChampSim CPU microarchitecture simulator. It will use microbenchmarks to expose specific CPU event types (e.g., cache misses, branch mispredictions) and compare the simulator's behavior to real hardware. The goal is to identify performance-critical events that ChampSim models accurately and areas where it falls short. Potential outcomes include identifying simulator limitations and proposing improvements. The project is part of a larger effort to understand trade-offs in CPU simulators.

4039.title: RAY TRACING DATA STRUCTURES (with ARM Trondheim)
4039.summary: This project focuses on implementing and evaluating ray tracing acceleration structures, specifically Bounding Volume Hierarchies (BVHs), for real-time graphics applications on ARM hardware. The student will implement a standard BVH construction algorithm (SAH or LBVH) on the CPU, with potential Vulkan Compute implementation. Performance will be evaluated based on build time, memory footprint, and impact on framerate. The project aims to establish a foundation for a Master's thesis exploring improvements to BVH construction algorithms.

4042.title: Memetic and Multimethod Stochastic Optimization Algorithms
4042.summary: This project explores memetic and multi-method stochastic optimization algorithms, integrating stochastic local search (SLS) and evolutionary algorithms (EAs) for solving computationally hard problems. The research will focus on addressing limitations in current stochastic optimization, particularly for multimodal functions, by combining SLS, EA, clustering, and feedback control. The goal is to empirically test a multi-method algorithm on synthetic and natural combinatorial optimization problems, including machine learning tasks like feature selection, and to establish performance relative to existing methods.

4043.title: Implementation and Evaluation of Scalar Evolution Analysis
4043.summary: This project focuses on implementing and evaluating a scalar evolution analysis within the JLM compiler, which utilizes the Regionalized Value State Dependence Graph (RVSDG) intermediate representation. The goal is to analyze how scalar variables change within loops to enable loop optimizations and simplifications. The project involves understanding scalar evolution theory, the RVSDG, and the JLM compiler's codebase. The implementation will be done in C++ using the LLVM infrastructure, and the evaluation will assess the impact of the analysis on loop transformations.

4044.title: Efficient Instruction Scheduling for High-Performance Cores
4044.summary: This project aims to improve instruction scheduling in high-performance cores by leveraging instruction dependencies learned during register renaming. It involves understanding existing in-order and out-of-order scheduling techniques, particularly within the gem5 simulator. The core task is to identify and implement benefits from instruction dependencies gained during register renaming within gem5, followed by evaluation and analysis. The project may also explore implementing techniques in Rocket or BOOM RISC-V cores.

4045.title: Explaining AI-based Recommendations (with Sparebank 1 SMN)
4045.summary: This project explores Explainable AI (XAI) methods to understand AI-driven recommendations in banking. Using a large dataset from Sparebank 1 SMN, the student will analyze complex models' outputs to provide explanations for product recommendations. The research aims to enhance the transparency of AI systems, enabling employees to understand the reasoning behind suggestions. The project will be supervised by Stian Arntsen (Sparebank 1 SMN) and Inga Strümke (NTNU).

4046.title: Chisel for Machine Learning
4046.summary: This project aims to extend the capabilities of chisel4ml, a Chisel-based framework for developing low-latency machine learning algorithms, potentially for larger models and networks. The research involves understanding machine learning inference accelerators and evaluating different hardware implementations. The project requires expertise in hardware description languages (VHDL, Verilog, or Chisel) and familiarity with AI training and ONNX. Expected outcomes include extending the chisel4ml framework to support more ML models or target platforms.

4047.title: Algorithmic Problems (2025)
4047.summary: This project explores algorithmic problems, offering flexibility in research focus. Potential areas include developing new algorithms/data structures, analyzing existing solutions theoretically, implementing and benchmarking algorithms, exploring new applications, or combining solutions and problems. The project encourages students to brainstorm applications in areas of interest, even outside computer science, to identify relevant problems. Collaboration between students is possible and encouraged.

4048.title: Rare Anomaly Detection in Time Series (with SINTEF, Statnett)
4048.summary: This project focuses on developing anomaly detection models for voltage transformer time series data from Statnett, aiming to improve maintenance prediction. The research will explore methods to identify rare anomalies indicative of maintenance needs by analyzing deviations between the three phases of voltage data. The project will address challenges posed by unlabelled data, varying data quality, and dynamic system externalities. The expected outcome is an improved anomaly detection algorithm that can predict drift early and estimate the time until a threshold is reached, enabling proactive maintenance.

4049.title: LLMs for Maritime language
4049.summary: This project explores the application of Large Language Models (LLMs) to the maritime domain. It investigates fine-tuning, continued pre-training, and Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) techniques using maritime-specific documents. The goal is to optimize LLMs for maritime language use cases, such as question answering related to maritime regulations. The project will be co-supervised by Børge Rokseth and Rudolf Mester.

4050.title: AI-powered Data Extraction from Archival Records (with Arkivverket)
4050.summary: This project explores using AI, specifically Large Language Models and image recognition, to improve the digital accessibility of historical records at the National Archives. The research will focus on a specific data source provided by the Archives, such as handwritten documents or pre-19th century records. The expected outcome is a method for enhanced data extraction and accessibility, evaluated in collaboration with experts from the National Archives.

4051.title: Interoperability of Learning Systems
4051.summary: This project investigates learning system interoperability using xAPI and LTI standards to integrate data from platforms like FS, Canvas, and Sikt within the Norwegian educational ecosystem. The goal is to develop a prototype system that accesses and aggregates learning activity data via APIs, creating a dashboard for visualizing cross-system learning data. The project involves literature review, system architecture design, implementation of data access modules, dashboard development, and system evaluation, ultimately providing stakeholders with insights into learning progress and resource usage.

4052.title: AI-Powered Processing of Public Consultation Responses
4052.summary: This project explores using AI-powered text analysis to automate the processing of public consultation responses for Oslo Municipality. It aims to develop an AI pipeline using Large Language Models (LLMs) for categorization, clustering, and summarization of textual feedback. The project will compare the AI pipeline's performance against manual analysis in terms of quality and speed, utilizing a dataset provided by Oslo Municipality for fine-tuning. Expected outcomes include a proof-of-concept pipeline and an assessment of AI's impact on efficiency and bias reduction in public consultation analysis.

4053.title: Control and monitoring of robots through intuitive and natural language interactions
4053.summary: This project explores using Large Language Models (LLMs) to improve robot control through natural language. The research focuses on developing an LLM-based model that translates natural language instructions into formal mission specifications in Planning Domain Definition Language (PDDL). The expected outcome is a system capable of generating verifiable robot mission plans from intuitive natural language input. The project involves collaboration with SINTEF and potential access to their robot lab for model verification.

4054.title: Applying ChatGPT for Data Integration
4054.summary: This project explores using Large Language Models (LLMs) like ChatGPT for data integration from heterogeneous sources. It involves prompt engineering and fine-tuning LLMs, comparing the resulting implementation to traditional data integration methods. The project will assess the potential and risks of using LLMs for data integration, with the goal of providing a proof-of-concept implementation.

4055.title: From Interview Transcription to Article Draft
4055.summary: This project explores using Large Language Models (LLMs) to automate article drafting from interview transcriptions. The research involves fine-tuning models like GPT, Llama, Mistral, Gemini, or DeepSeek on a dataset of Norwegian interviews and articles from Adressavisen. The primary goal is to develop an AI capable of summarizing key messages and generating article drafts. Journalists will evaluate the quality of the generated drafts in a user study.

4056.title: GPU adaptations of 3D shape matching algorithms
4056.summary: This project explores GPU adaptations of 3D shape matching algorithms to improve performance. The research focuses on parallelizing existing CPU-based algorithms for implementation on GPUs, addressing challenges related to memory bandwidth and non-direct GPU mappings. The expected outcome is faster execution times, enabling practical applications of 3D shape matching in areas like robotics.

4057.title: Secure player data management
4057.summary: This project explores technical solutions for secure player data management in football, addressing the FIFPRO Charter of Player Data Rights. It investigates distributed storage and data governance to protect player privacy, control data collection, and ensure portability. The project involves a literature review, threat modeling, and the development of a proof-of-concept. Expected outcomes include supporting positive data usage for player development, injury prevention, fan engagement, and economic compensation, with potential user testing involving football players.

4058.title: Simulation of artefacts caused by 3D capturing devices
4058.summary: This project proposes developing algorithms to simulate 3D scanning artifacts (noise, occlusion, clutter) on existing 3D meshes. The goal is to create a scalable and cost-effective benchmark for evaluating 3D shape matching algorithms used in applications like self-driving cars. By simulating artifacts from techniques like LiDAR and photogrammetry, the project aims to provide a controlled environment for testing matching algorithms under various conditions, isolating the impact of individual artifacts.

4059.title: Keypoint detection through destructive clustering for 3D shape recognition
4059.summary: This project proposes a novel keypoint detection method for 3D shape recognition in SLAM, using destructive clustering to identify unique features. The research will develop a keypoint detector that leverages an index tree of 3D surface patches, removing non-unique surfaces based on previously seen data. Expected outcomes include identifying characteristics of unique surfaces in large datasets and evaluating the potential for real-time localization in 3D scans using the proposed methodology. Technologies involved include 3D shape descriptors and index trees.

4060.title: Automating Compliance Processes in the Banking Industry
4060.summary: This project develops an Agentic AI system to automate compliance analysis in the banking industry, focusing on Visa products and services. The system will interpret compliance documents, map requirements to products, and generate compliance reports. Key technologies include Agentic AI, document understanding, and machine learning for summarization and action recommendations. The project will culminate in a web UI for accessing compliance information and exporting analysis results, aiming to improve efficiency and accuracy in compliance management.

4061.title: Sustainable open source projects: evaluating sustainability practices of open source projects
4061.summary: This project investigates the sustainability of open source software (OSS) by examining social, technical, and organizational factors influencing their long-term success. It involves a literature review, analysis of successful and unsuccessful OSS projects, and qualitative interviews or surveys with OSS community members. The research aims to identify key sustainability practices and failure points, ultimately providing actionable insights and best practices to enhance the longevity and resilience of open source projects.

4062.title: Eco-friendly mobile app development: developing guidelines for Creating Mobile Applications that Minimize Energy Consumption and Resource Use
4062.summary: This master's project proposes developing guidelines for eco-friendly mobile app development to minimize energy consumption and resource use. The research will involve a literature review, benchmark analysis of existing apps' energy consumption, and qualitative interviews with developers. The project aims to identify design principles, coding practices, and architectural strategies that contribute to sustainable mobile applications. The expected outcome is a set of practical guidelines for developers to create energy-efficient mobile apps, reducing their environmental impact.

4064.title: How can we evaluate the extent to which a 3D shape matching algorithm is affected by differences in colour?
4064.summary: This project aims to develop a benchmark for evaluating the impact of color variations on 3D shape matching algorithms. It will extend an existing shape-based benchmark to include factors influencing object appearance, such as lighting, shininess, and translucency. The research will leverage the expertise of the color lab in Gjøvik. The expected outcome is a tool for assessing the robustness of 3D shape matching algorithms to color differences.

4065.title: IoT Aquarium
4065.summary: This project focuses on developing an IoT-enabled freshwater aquarium with a user-friendly web application for remote monitoring and interaction. It involves researching existing solutions, designing and prototyping both the IoT components and software, and conducting user testing. The expected outcome is a functional aquarium system with remote monitoring and control capabilities accessible through a web interface.

4066.title: IoT Garden Bed
4066.summary: This project focuses on developing an IoT-enabled garden bed with a user-friendly web application for remote monitoring and control. It involves researching existing solutions, designing and prototyping both the IoT hardware/software components, and conducting user testing to evaluate the system's usability. The expected outcome is a functional smart garden bed system and a usable web interface.

4067.title: Measuring the Coding Experience
4067.summary: This project investigates the coding experience using biometric sensors (EEG, eye tracking, GSR) to analyze cognitive load and engagement. User tests will be conducted, potentially comparing coding tasks with and without AI assistance. The project involves literature review, experiment design, data collection, and analysis. Expected outcomes include insights into the learning process and the development of data processing scripts or visualizations.

4070.title: Design for IT and Sustainability
4070.summary: This project focuses on designing a playful learning tool to enhance informatics students' understanding of IT sustainability and its integration into design. The project involves modifying the Tiles toolkit to foster reflection on sustainability. The outcome will be a physical, online, or hybrid toolkit, developed through design, prototyping, and evaluation, to promote sustainability awareness in IT design.

4071.title: AI Powered Formative Assessment for Open-text Questions
4071.summary: This project aims to develop an AI-powered formative assessment tool for open-text questions. Using NLP and AI, the system will analyze student responses, providing teachers with a real-time dashboard indicating the percentage of students with correct, partially correct, or incorrect answers. The goal is to enable adaptive feedback, identify knowledge gaps, and dynamically adjust lectures. The solution's effectiveness will be tested in real lecture environments, contributing to AI-driven education technologies and enhancing teaching and learning experiences.

4073.title: Games - Games for reflection on ethical aspects of IT tools
4073.summary: This project proposes developing and evaluating a game to promote reflection and discussion on ethical issues related to IT tools among informatics students. Building upon existing work in ethics education for informatics, the project aims to address concerns like algorithmic bias, data privacy, and sustainable design. The expected outcome is a game that effectively facilitates ethical considerations within the context of software development and usage.

4074.title: Agile Question Generation in Student Response Systems
4074.summary: This project explores agile question generation in student response systems, aiming to create contextually relevant follow-up questions from open-text student responses during lectures. It addresses the limitations of current systems that lack flexibility in ad hoc question generation. The project will leverage AI and NLP to analyze student input and generate meaningful questions in real-time. The effectiveness will be evaluated through user studies, focusing on student engagement, learning outcomes, and teaching adaptability.

4075.title: Generative AI and Computational Creative Artform Transitions (e.g., Text to Images, Images to Music or Music to Text)
4075.summary: This project explores generative AI's role in computational creativity, focusing on transitions between art forms. It investigates using AI models to generate art in one medium (e.g., music, images) from another (e.g., text, images). The research aims to understand how AI can produce, understand, or evaluate creativity across different domains, potentially leading to systems that support human creativity by bridging the gap between various artistic expressions.

4076.title: Discovery of program control flow in binary programs from unknown instruction set architectures
4076.summary: This project focuses on developing a heuristic method for reverse engineering binary programs with unknown instruction set architectures (ISAs). The goal is to extract program control flow information, including subroutine structures (CALL/RET), branch/jump statements, and entry points, without prior knowledge of the ISA. The project will involve analyzing binary programs and using Python to implement the heuristic method. The expected outcome is a tool capable of automatically discovering control flow in binaries from undocumented or custom ISAs.

4077.title: Detecting Social Media Risk Users
