4077.summary: This project explores the detection of at-risk users on social media for security and mental health purposes. It will apply machine learning techniques, potentially including deep learning, to social media text data. The goal is to identify users at risk of radicalization, exploitation, or exhibiting signs of mental health issues. The project will involve gathering and utilizing substantial datasets to train and evaluate the machine learning models.

4081.title: Games - Ready for digital transformation
4081.summary: This project proposes designing a game to enhance workers' understanding of new technologies and their impact in the workplace, focusing on systemic and critical thinking. The project involves defining specific learning objectives, selecting a game genre and technology, and includes design, prototyping, and evaluation. The expected outcome is a game that effectively promotes competence in navigating digital transformation.

4083.title: Games - Reflective and collaborative games for learning about creativity and AI
4083.summary: This project explores using AI to support creativity through the design and evaluation of a game. The game will focus on the ethical and responsible use of AI in creative processes, potentially targeting specific workplaces. Students will define the game's learning objectives, genre, and technology in collaboration with the supervisor. The expected outcome is an understanding of how AI can foster creativity, with potential for further development into a master's thesis involving game design and evaluation.

4084.title: IMTEL - Supporting learning with cutting-edge XR technology: Apple Vision Pro, VR treadmill and haptic suit/gloves (COPY)
4084.summary: This project explores the use of advanced XR technology like Apple Vision Pro, VR treadmills, and haptic suits/gloves to enhance learning experiences at the university and professional levels. The research will focus on how these technologies can support education through advanced 3D visualization, spatial computing games, and simulations requiring haptic feedback. The expected outcome is to demonstrate the potential of cutting-edge XR equipment in creating more engaging and effective learning environments. The project will utilize the resources of the IMTEL VR lab.

4087.title: The Norwegian impact on the (lack of) sustainability of computing
4087.summary: This project investigates the sustainability of ICT from a Norwegian perspective, considering the global impact of computing infrastructure supply chains despite Norway's carbon-free energy. It will analyze the adverse effects of computing in Norway on other parts of the world, using approaches like ACT and FOCAL. The research aims to understand the overall environmental impact of ICT, including carbon emissions, energy consumption, and water usage.

4088.title: Discovery of ISA features from binary programs from unknown instruction set architectures
4088.summary: This project focuses on reverse engineering binary programs from unknown instruction set architectures (ISAs). The goal is to develop a heuristic method, using Python, to automatically extract key ISA features, including word size, endianness, number of registers, instruction format (fixed or variable width), instruction width, and opcode encoding. The expected outcome is a tool capable of identifying these features, aiding in the disassembly and analysis of binaries with undocumented or unknown ISAs.

4089.title: Sentiment and/or Figurative Language Analysis in Social Media
4089.summary: This project focuses on sentiment analysis of social media texts, specifically addressing the challenges posed by negation and figurative language (sarcasm, irony, metaphor). The primary goal is to automatically classify the sentiment expressed in social media posts as positive or negative, and potentially quantify the degree of sentiment. The project involves identifying a dataset of social media posts rich in figurative language and developing methods to accurately determine sentiment despite the indirect meanings conveyed.

4091.title: Identifying Online Hate Speech and Cyber Bullying
4091.summary: This project investigates machine learning methods for identifying hate speech and cyberbullying in online user-generated content. It will analyze existing flame-annotated datasets from platforms like chat rooms, online games, Wikipedia, and X/Twitter. The research will explore and implement various machine learning techniques to automate the detection of abusive language, aiming to improve moderation efficiency and reduce the time harmful content remains online.

4092.title: Generativ KI og kritisk tenking
4092.summary: This master's project explores the impact of generative AI tools like ChatGPT on critical thinking abilities. The research will employ empirical qualitative methods, including literature reviews and a case study involving observations, interviews, and archival data. The goal is to understand how the increasing use of generative AI, with its inherent biases and potential for hallucination, affects the ability to critically evaluate information. The specific case and focus will be developed in collaboration with the student.

4093.title: Smidig droneutvikling
4093.summary: This project investigates agile development practices in drone technology, focusing on the Norwegian defense sector. It aims to identify best practices through literature review and explore the perspectives of Norwegian defense startups and drone companies via case study methodology. The research will employ qualitative data collection methods like observations, interviews, and archival data. Expected outcomes include insights into the preparedness of Norway and its suppliers for rapid drone technology development and recommendations for improvement.

4094.title: Multi-agent systemer i organisasjoner
4094.summary: This project explores the application of Multi-Agent Systems (MAS) to enhance AI utilization within organizations by facilitating interaction between technical agents and humans. Employing action-design research, the study will design, develop, and evaluate a MAS in a real-world setting through observations and interviews. The research involves literature reviews, requirements gathering, system development, and evaluation. The specific problem and organizational context will be defined in collaboration with SINTEF Digital's partner companies. Expected outcomes include insights into the effectiveness of MAS in organizational settings and a functional prototype.

4095.title: QDA-Flow ("Qualitative Data Analysis"-Flow): En modulær pipeline for analyse av kvalitative intervju-transkripsjoner
4095.summary: This project proposes developing QDA-Flow, a modular Python pipeline for qualitative data analysis of interview transcripts. It will leverage NLP, thematic analysis, network analysis, and visualization techniques to extract insights such as word clouds, thematic clusters, relationship maps, sentiment analysis, and metadata-driven filtering. The project follows action-design-research principles, evaluating the pipeline's practical impact with researchers. Expected outcomes include a documented prototype pipeline and insights into its effectiveness in real-world qualitative research.

4096.title: Biologically Plausible Artificial Intelligence
4096.summary: This project explores biologically plausible learning rules to create more robust AI models, moving beyond backpropagation to address issues like catastrophic forgetting. It builds upon existing research in unsupervised learning and online clustering, potentially extending work on robust image/sound representations. The project may involve parallelization and implementation on specialized hardware like FPGAs/ASICs. Expected outcomes include advancements in biologically plausible learning and more resilient machine learning models.

4097.title: Architecture-based reliability evaluation of machine learning pipelines
4097.summary: This project explores architecture-based reliability evaluation of machine learning pipelines. It aims to adapt existing reliability modeling techniques, like Fault Trees, to ML pipelines by deriving models from pipeline diagrams (e.g., using Netron). The project involves a literature review, defining a method for deriving reliability models, and adapting it to a semester-long task. Expected outcomes include a method for evaluating and comparing ML architectures based on fault tolerance. Skills required include ML, Python, and Git.

4098.title: Co-design of courses: Digital Competencies 4 ALL
4098.summary: This project explores the co-design of lifelong learning courses, addressing the gap in knowledge on creating relevant training for specific workplaces. The project aims to design and evaluate a playful toolkit, inspired by board games and card-based co-design tools, to involve learners in the co-design of their learning experiences. The research will focus on understanding lifelong learning principles and co-design methodologies, potentially leading to a master's thesis on the toolkit's design and evaluation.

4099.title: Digital platform fairness
4099.summary: This project investigates platform fairness, focusing on the relationship between platform core and periphery to identify design ideas for fairer platforms. The research employs empirical qualitative methods, gathering data from platforms like Foodora, Uber, or temp agencies. Expected outcomes include a deeper understanding of platform fairness and actionable design insights. The thesis can be written in Norwegian or English.

4100.title: Reliability evaluation of approximate computing techniques
4100.summary: This project evaluates the reliability of approximate computing techniques by applying fault injection. It focuses on compiler-level approximate computing and code-level fault injection. The goal is to compare different approximate computing algorithms based on their fault tolerance. The project involves extending an existing approximate computing benchmark with a fault tolerance perspective and executing algorithms on this extended benchmark. Expected outcomes include a literature review on reliability of approximate computing software and an evaluation of the fault tolerance of different algorithms. Technologies used include C/C++ and CMake.

4101.title: Competency frameworks made useful
4101.summary: This project focuses on developing a tool that makes competency frameworks more accessible and useful for individual professional development. It involves designing, prototyping, and evaluating a playful, cooperative, and reflective tool for self-assessment against competency frameworks, specifically "ResearchComp." The expected outcome is a prototype adaptable to different frameworks, enabling users to effectively plan their professional development.

4102.title: Collaboration between AI and knowledge workers
4102.summary: This master's project explores human-AI collaboration in knowledge organizations, focusing on how knowledge workers interact with AI technologies. Using empirical research methods like case studies or design science, the project aims to generate new knowledge, collaboration models, or interaction designs. The research will investigate specific AI types and work practices, with the outcome being empirical insights and potentially new models for human-AI collaboration. Proficiency in qualitative research is required.

4103.title: Define your own topic in software and systems reliability
4103.summary: This master's project explores software and system reliability, safety, and security. The student will define a specific research topic within this area, potentially involving reliability/safety/security modeling at the architecture level, formal methods like model checking, fault injection, or testing techniques. The expected outcome is a comprehensive study and potential advancements within the chosen area of software and system reliability.

4104.title: Define your own topic in software and systems modeling
4104.summary: This master's project focuses on software and systems modeling, allowing students to define a topic of their interest within the field. Potential areas include architectural modeling, formal methods like model checking, and the definition of Domain-Specific Languages (DSLs) and metamodels. The expected outcome is a master's project that contributes to the student's chosen area of software and systems modeling.

4105.title: Defining a metamodel for concepts related to LLMs and generative AI
4105.summary: This project aims to define a metamodel and Domain-Specific Language (DSL) for concepts related to Large Language Models (LLMs) and Generative AI (GenAI) in software engineering. The DSL will enable standardized documentation of GenAI component usage within software systems' architectures. The research contributes to a methodology for specifying and documenting GenAI components. Skills required include abstraction, modeling, and basic GenAI knowledge.

4106.title: Software architecure modeling of AI-enabled systems
4106.summary: This project explores the use of Architecture Description Languages (ADLs) for modeling software architectures that incorporate AI components. It involves a literature review and experimentation with existing ADLs like UML, SysML, and AADL to identify their limitations in representing AI-specific concepts such as AI models, prompt patterns, and AI agents. The expected outcome is to define modeling languages and patterns tailored for specifying software architectures of AI-enabled systems.

4107.title: Using LLMs for configuring static analysis tools
4107.summary: This project explores using Large Language Models (LLMs) to simplify the configuration of static analysis tools like SonarQube and PMD, focusing on custom rule definition. The research involves training LLMs to translate natural language rule descriptions into tool configurations, using existing open-source rulesets as training data. The project includes a literature review, experimentation with open-source LLMs, and performance evaluation. Expected outcomes include insights into the feasibility of using GenAI to ease the definition and verification of coding rules.

4108.title: Life-long learning models for digital transformation
4108.summary: This project explores lifelong learning models for professionals adapting to digital transformation. It focuses on developing pedagogical approaches for busy individuals who need to continuously update their skills. The research will employ empirical qualitative methods like co-design and case studies to generate knowledge and design ideas for new learning models and tools. Expected outcomes include new insights and practical models for on-the-job learning.

4109.title: Agile Question Generation in Student Response Systems
4109.summary: This project explores agile question generation in student response systems, aiming to create contextually relevant follow-up questions from open-text student responses during lectures. It addresses the limitations of existing systems that lack flexibility in ad hoc question generation. The project will leverage AI and NLP to analyze student input and generate meaningful questions in real-time. The effectiveness will be evaluated through user studies, focusing on student engagement, learning outcomes, and teaching adaptability.

4110.title: AI Powered Formative Assessment for Open-text Questions
4110.summary: This project aims to develop an AI-powered formative assessment tool for open-text questions. Using NLP and AI, the system will analyze student responses to provide teachers with a real-time dashboard indicating the percentage of students with correct, partially correct, or incorrect answers. The goal is to enable adaptive feedback, identify knowledge gaps, and improve teaching effectiveness. The solution will be tested in real lecture environments, contributing to AI-driven education technologies.

4111.title: Fake News/Disinformation Detection
4111.summary: This project explores methods for detecting fake news from online sources using machine learning, natural language processing, and semantic web technologies. The research aims to analyze news articles from various sources to efficiently distinguish between real and fake news. The expected outcome is an effective approach for fake news/disinformation detection.

4112.title: Characteristics of successful AI-Adoption in large organizations: OsloKommune
4112.summary: This project investigates successful AI adoption characteristics within OsloKommune's newly established AI factory. It involves analyzing the AI factory, mapping AI implementation stories, and identifying success/failure factors using technology adoption frameworks. The goal is to develop a holistic understanding of AI adoption aspects, potentially creating an AI adoption toolbox tailored for the municipal context. Expected outcomes include insights for widespread AI adoption, prioritized efforts, best practices, and positioning OsloKommune as an AI leader.

4116.title: Trust and quality in AI-generated map data: Kartverket
4116.summary: This project explores how explainable AI (XAI) can foster trust and credibility in AI-generated map data within the public sector, specifically in collaboration with Kartverket. Focusing on a case study of AI-driven analysis and visualization of map data, the research adopts a sociotechnical perspective to address the challenge of ensuring reliability and verifiability in automated spatial data analytics. The expected outcome is the development of guidelines for XAI implementation in public data services.

4117.title: Multimodal Knowledge Graph for Digital Twins
4117.summary: This project explores the creation of a multimodal knowledge graph for digital twins, leveraging data from diverse sources. The research focuses on integrating and representing information to enhance the capabilities of digital twins. Expected outcomes include a functional knowledge graph capable of supporting advanced analytics, simulations, and decision-making within digital twin environments.

4119.title: Benchmarking framework for multi-model vector search
4119.summary: This project focuses on developing a benchmarking framework for multi-model vector search, enabling efficient experimentation with various algorithms, indexes, and datasets. The project involves studying existing approaches, creating an extensible framework (based on a pre-existing prototype), and testing current algorithms within it. The framework will be implemented in C++ and will use pre-trained embeddings. The expected outcome is a tool for evaluating and comparing multi-modal vector search techniques.

4120.title: Scalable multi-model vector search
4120.summary: This project explores scalable approximate vector search for multi-modal data, focusing on datasets exceeding the capacity of current indexing methods. The research involves studying existing techniques, developing or extending solutions, and implementing/evaluating them on large datasets using pre-trained embeddings. The project will likely leverage ideas from DiskANN. Expected outcomes include novel algorithms or indexing techniques for efficient large-scale vector search and a performance evaluation on a large dataset. Strong C++ programming skills are required.

4121.title: *NEW*: AI-Driven Multi-Modal Perception for Autonomous Systems Using LiDAR and Stereo Vision (2025-2026)
4121.summary: This project explores AI-driven fusion of LiDAR and stereo vision for enhanced perception in autonomous systems. It aims to improve environmental understanding for navigation, obstacle detection, and object recognition. The research will leverage AI to create adaptable perception systems and can be applied to platforms like the BlueBoat, milliAmpere2 ferry, NTNU Revolve racing cars, or the AgileX LIMO robot. Expected outcomes include more accurate and robust perception capabilities for autonomous mobile systems.

4127.title: *NEW*:   AI Projects related to Salmon Health Tracking  (7 different projects)
4127.summary: The master's project focuses on applying AI to enhance salmon health tracking in aquaculture. It explores various AI techniques, including unsupervised learning, semantic segmentation using stereo vision, behavioral analysis, automated annotation, re-identification, 3D modeling from monocular videos, and pose estimation from stereo images. The projects aim to develop automated systems for welfare assessment, individual fish identification, and precise size/mass estimation, ultimately improving fish farming practices through advanced computer vision and machine learning.

4128.title: *NEW*:  Effective Sample Selection for Training Maritime Object Detection Models  (coop. with Maritime Robotics)
4128.summary: This project explores effective sample selection strategies for training maritime object detection models, crucial for Unmanned Surface Vessels (USV). It aims to minimize annotation effort by identifying the most informative samples using domain knowledge and active learning techniques. The research involves implementing online sample selection algorithms, evaluating their performance against random sampling, and analyzing the trade-offs between real-time and offline processing. The expected outcome is a more efficient method for creating training datasets, improving the performance of object detection models on USVs.

4129.title: *NEW*:  Instance Segmentation for Unmanned Surface Vessels Fusing LIDAR and Camera  (in coop. with Maritime Robotics)
4129.summary: This project explores fusing LIDAR and camera data for 2D instance segmentation on Unmanned Surface Vessels (USVs), focusing on near-shore object detection. The research involves developing a detection model that integrates LIDAR point clouds with camera images, using YOLO as a baseline. It will evaluate different fusion techniques to improve detection accuracy compared to camera-only methods. The model will be integrated into Maritime Robotics' SeaSight system for experimental validation on the Otter USV.

4130.title: *NEW* Temporal-YOLO:   Making object detectors stable and reliable
4130.summary: This project aims to improve the temporal stability of YOLO object detectors in video streams by reducing flickering and multiple detections. It proposes a time-aware YOLO version that incorporates the history of previous detections using a fusion of machine learning models and temporal statistical processes. The expected outcome is a smoother, more reliable sequence of bounding boxes and object masks. The project combines deep learning with statistical detection theory.

4131.title: Generative AI and solving math word problems
4131.summary: This project explores using Generative AI, specifically LLMs like GPT, LLaMA, or Mistral, to solve mathematical word problems. It involves curating datasets, fine-tuning models, and evaluating their accuracy and reasoning compared to traditional methods. The research aims to develop an AI model capable of interpreting and solving word problems, analyzing its limitations, and exploring educational applications. The project requires Python/Java programming skills and a background in machine learning.

4132.title: Generative AI and solving visual math problems
4132.summary: This project explores using Generative AI to solve visual math problems by developing AI models capable of interpreting and reasoning through mathematical problems presented in visual formats. It involves multimodal AI (text + image) and evaluates AI’s ability to generalize across different visual math challenges. The project includes dataset curation, model selection & training, and performance assessment using accuracy and reasoning steps. Expected outcomes include insights into AI's role in mathematical reasoning and potential applications in education and automated assessment.

4133.title: Generative AI and Usability testing
4133.summary: This project investigates Generative AI's role in automating and enhancing software usability testing. It aims to explore AI's potential in automating usability testing, generating UX reports, and providing feedback. The project will compare AI-driven insights with traditional methods and human expert evaluations. The expected outcome is an understanding of the benefits, challenges, and limitations of using GenAI for usability testing, including empirical studies on AI-generated recommendations. The project requires Python/Java programming skills and a background in system design and machine learning.

4134.title: Generative AI and Code generation from legacy diagrams
4134.summary: This project explores using Generative AI to automate code generation from legacy diagrams (UML, flowcharts). It involves developing a pipeline to convert diagrams into structured representations (JSON, AST) and using models like GPT-4 or multimodal models to generate functional code. The project includes literature review, model testing/fine-tuning, usability testing with developers, and evaluation based on accuracy and maintainability. The ideal candidate should have a background in system design, basic machine learning, and solid programming skills in Python/Java.

4135.title: Generative AI and Domain Specific Languages
4135.summary: This project explores using Generative AI (GenAI) to enhance Domain-Specific Language (DSL) development and usability. It aims to create a framework integrating GenAI into DSL lifecycles, evaluating AI-generated code against human-written code for correctness and efficiency. The research involves fine-tuning GenAI models for DSL tasks, conducting user studies to assess AI-assisted improvements, and proposing guidelines for AI-friendly DSL design. Expected outcomes include a prototype tool, usability improvements, and insights into leveraging GenAI for DSL automation.

4136.title: Generative AI and green web design
4136.summary: This project investigates the application of Generative AI (GenAI) to enhance green web design, focusing on reducing the environmental impact of web development. It aims to develop and evaluate AI-generated web design solutions using models like GPT-4, assessing their energy consumption, usability, and carbon footprint compared to traditional methods. The research will involve implementing AI-driven designs, conducting usability testing, and employing tools like Lighthouse and Ecograder for performance analysis, ultimately exploring trade-offs between usability, aesthetics, and sustainability in AI-driven web design.

4137.title: Generative AI and green coding
4137.summary: This project explores using Generative AI (GenAI) to enhance green coding practices by automatically generating and optimizing energy-efficient code. It involves developing or analyzing an AI-powered green coding assistant using models like GPT, Codex, or CodeT5. The project will evaluate the energy consumption of AI-generated code against human-written code using tools like Intel VTune and conduct usability testing to assess developer experience. Expected outcomes include identifying best practices for integrating GenAI into sustainable software development and recommendations for improving energy efficiency in real-world applications.

4138.title: AI, Biometrics and Extreme programming
4138.summary: This project explores the use of AI and biometrics (eye-tracking, EEG, facial expressions) to analyze successful extreme programming (XP) sessions. The goal is to identify key features of successful XP and develop AI-driven feedback tools for students. The project involves literature review, data collection, AI pipeline design, and potentially the design and evaluation of a feedback system. The project requires a background in system design, machine learning, and strong programming skills in Python/Java. Expected outcomes include insights into XP processes and potentially a functional feedback system.

4139.title: AI, eye-tracking and Understanding teachers
4139.summary: This project explores teacher cognition using AI-enhanced eye-tracking. It aims to analyze teachers' visual attention, cognitive load, and decision-making processes in classrooms. The research will involve collecting eye-tracking data from teachers in simulated or real classroom settings, using AI to analyze gaze patterns, and correlating these patterns with instructional choices. Expected outcomes include insights into teacher behavior, improved teacher training methods, and the development of adaptive AI systems for real-time support. The project requires a background in system design, machine learning, and programming skills in Python/Java.

4140.title: Mental Health and wellbeing in Computing Education
4140.summary: This project investigates mental health challenges in computing education, analyzing their impact on student performance and career goals. It will evaluate existing support systems and propose interventions like curriculum changes, AI-based support tools, or mindfulness practices. The research employs surveys, interviews, and case studies. Optional intervention testing may be included. The project requires a background in system design and basic machine learning, along with Python/Java programming skills. Expected outcomes include identified challenges, evaluated support systems, and proposed strategies to enhance student wellbeing.

4141.title: Improving health literacy using gamification
4141.summary: This project investigates gamification's potential to improve health literacy by designing and evaluating a gamified learning system. The research involves developing a prototype application incorporating game elements like points, quests, and feedback. User testing will assess engagement, knowledge retention, and satisfaction compared to traditional methods. The project aims to identify design principles for effective gamified health education tools, requiring skills in system design, programming (Python/Java), and basic machine learning. Expected outcomes include insights into gamification's impact on health literacy and a functional prototype.

4142.title: A Multimodal (Video and Audio) Approach to Developing a Recommender System using Content Narrative of Online Streamed Video Games (YouTube/Twitch)
4142.summary: This project aims to develop a multimodal (video and audio) recommender system for online streamed video games using deep learning. The system will classify gaming videos into emotional and thematic categories by extracting features using computer vision and NLP techniques. Temporal models (LSTMs/Transformers) will ensure coherent classification. The expected outcome is a system that automatically generates content breakdowns of gaming streams (e.g., % exploration, combat, narrative) to enable a narrative-based video game recommendation system.

4143.title: AD - AI-agents trained end-to-end by Imitation and Reinforcement learning in simulated environments (2025)
4143.summary: This project explores training AI agents for autonomous driving using deep reinforcement learning and imitation learning in simulated environments like CARLA, NVIDIA Omniverse, and MARS. The research will investigate state-of-the-art approaches such as UniAD and MILE, and leverage real-world data by creating a virtual replica of the local campus area (Gløs). The expected outcome is an AI agent capable of navigating complex simulated environments, potentially leading to advancements in autonomous driving technology.

4144.title: AD (Autonomous Driving), AI/ML/DL and Computer Vision (CV) (2025)
4144.summary: This project explores autonomous driving (AD) using AI/ML/DL and computer vision, leveraging NAP-lab's research platform. It investigates end-to-end (imitation/reinforcement learning) and modular AV approaches (mapping, perception, planning) using NVIDIA DRIVE/ROS. Research includes simulated environments (CARLA, NVIDIA DRIVE Sim, NeRF), domain adaptation, and AVs as mobile sensor platforms for digital road twins, focusing on challenging Nordic winter conditions and point cloud processing (LiDAR). Explores remote AV control via 5G. Expected outcomes include advancements in AD algorithms, sensor fusion techniques, and robust performance in diverse environments.

4145.title: AI-lab pitched projects - Master-project Safari (2025)
4145.summary: This master's project explores various AI applications across diverse fields. Projects include football analytics using video, medical image analysis for aortic aneurysms and brain segmentation, AI-based classification of laser point clouds for mapping, predicting GNSS measurement quality, point cloud streaming, monitoring nature loss with satellite imagery and AI, creating digital health twins, predicting fish locations for commercial fishing, and dense monocular depth estimation for unmanned surface vessels. The expected outcomes are improved analysis, prediction, and monitoring capabilities in each respective domain through the application of AI technologies.

4146.title: Autonomous Driving (AD): NAP-lab related projects based on Visual Intelligence (AI/CV)++ (2025)
4146.summary: This project explores various aspects of autonomous driving (AD) using visual intelligence (AI/CV) within the NAP-lab. Key areas include end-to-end AD, neural reconstruction for sim-to-real gap, TeleDrive, HD-maps/Digital Twins using NVIDIA Omniverse, control algorithms, crowdsourcing for map updates, and anonymization of camera data. The research utilizes a KIA e-Niro equipped with NVIDIA DRIVE AGX Orin, multiple sensors, and a drive-by-wire system, alongside CARLA and NVIDIA DRIVE Sim. Expected outcomes include advancements in AD algorithms, improved simulation fidelity, and contributions to digital road twin technology, potentially leading to publications and further research opportunities.

4147.title: Digital Twins (DTs) for Health and Infrastructure++ (2025)
4147.summary: This master's project explores the application of Digital Twins (DTs) for self-management of health and decision support in road infrastructure. The research aims to investigate and develop DT solutions within these two distinct domains. Expected outcomes include a functional DT prototype and insights into the feasibility and benefits of DT implementation in health and infrastructure.

4148.title: Driving with 3DGS/NeRFs: Simulating sensor inputs for autonomous driving agents (2025)
4148.summary: This project explores enhancing the nuPlan autonomous driving simulator with real-time camera input synthesis using Neural Radiance Fields (NeRFs) or 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS). It investigates how nuPlan data can aid view synthesis, evaluates the quality and speed of novel view generation, and assesses the usability of these synthesized views for training and evaluating end-to-end driving systems. The goal is to create a more comprehensive simulation environment for autonomous driving research.

4149.title: Industry (and AI-lab pitched) project proposals related to Visual intelligence (AI/CV) (2025)
4149.summary: This project explores various industry-related applications of Visual Intelligence (AI/CV). It includes projects focusing on health monitoring using digital twins, sports analytics for football video analysis, fouling analysis on test panels, grain size characterization of aluminum alloys, AI-assisted labeling of coronary arteries, autonomous driving in Nordic conditions, aerial laser classification, drone external inspection detection, and lobster handling in the food industry. The projects utilize technologies like deep learning, LiDAR, and video data analysis. Expected outcomes include improved diagnostic methods, enhanced autonomous navigation, and optimized industrial processes.

4150.title: MIC - Medical Image Computing / Analysis and AI/CV (most organs / most modalities) (2025)
4150.summary: This project focuses on medical image computing (MIC) using deep learning and computer vision techniques applied to various organs (heart, liver, lungs, brain, prostate, etc.) and modalities (CT, MR, ultrasound, digital pathology). The project aims to develop models, potentially using Vision Transformers (ViT), for tasks related to MIC, utilizing MONAI and MONAI Label. Expected outcomes include solutions to MIC challenges presented at conferences like MICCAI and CVPR, with a focus on practical applications in collaboration with MIRA, SINTEF Health, NTNU, and St. Olav hospital.

4151.title: 3DGS / NeRFs - photorealistic Reconstruction of complex 3D scenes (2025)
4151.summary: This project explores real-time photorealistic 3D scene reconstruction using Neural Radiance Fields (NeRFs) and potentially 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS). It involves understanding and experimenting with NeRF variants like Instant-NeRF and Block-NeRF. The research aims to apply these technologies in contexts such as autonomous driving simulators and VR/XR environments. Expected outcomes include a deeper understanding of NeRFs and their practical applications in creating realistic 3D representations.

4152.title: Omniverse, Content generation, Simulation and Digital Twins (2025)
4152.summary: This project aims to create a near real-time photorealistic digital twin of the Gløs campus using Omniverse and USD, leveraging existing geospatial data and real-time updates. The generated environment will be imported into simulators like DRIVE Sim and Isaac Sim for training autonomous driving agents using imitation and reinforcement learning. The AI models will be fine-tuned with real-world data and applied to an autonomous vehicle platform for research. The project also explores automated 3D content creation from 2D images.

4153.title: Óne citizen - óne digital health twin (an ecosystem of smart digital twins - towards a data-driven health service) (2025)
4153.summary: This project focuses on developing a "digital health twin" ecosystem, leveraging wearable data (smartwatches, health monitors) within the MIA Health platform. Key areas include expanding activity data integration, incorporating sleep data, and transitioning MIA from a data lake to a predictive digital twin using generic models and potentially fine-tuned LLMs. The project also explores novel clinical study methodologies and emphasizes privacy, security, and ethical considerations for health data within a cloud-based environment. Expected outcomes include enhanced user experience, improved preventative healthcare capabilities, and a robust architecture for managing and utilizing health data.

4154.title: Open Foundation Models / LLM (type ChatGPT), fine-tuned and adapted to Health and integrated in a Digital Twin setting (2025)
4154.summary: This project explores fine-tuning open-source Foundation Models/LLMs for health applications within a Digital Twin. It investigates model personalization using health data from wearables, integration for natural language interaction with a digital twin, and explainability methods. Key research areas include model selection, fine-tuning techniques, personalization strategies, and addressing privacy, security, and ethical challenges. The expected outcome is a personalized, health-focused LLM integrated into a Digital Twin environment, enabling natural conversation and providing knowledgeable health insights.

4155.title: Virtual, Augmented and Mixed Reality for learning AI etc. (2025)
4155.summary: This project explores the application of Virtual, Augmented, and Mixed Reality (XR) technologies to enhance learning and training experiences, specifically in fields like Artificial Intelligence (AI), Machine Learning (ML), and Deep Learning (DL), as well as medical case simulations. The expected outcome is to demonstrate the effectiveness of XR in improving knowledge acquisition and skill development in these complex domains.

4156.title: Vision Mamba for Advanced Medical Image Analysis (2025)
4156.summary: This project explores Vision Mamba (ViM) for medical image analysis, investigating its advantages over CNNs and Transformers. The research involves understanding ViM's theoretical foundations and implementing existing ViM architectures on medical image datasets. The project benchmarks ViM performance against CNNs and Transformers, with the potential to develop novel ViM architectures for improved performance. The balance between theoretical and practical implementation will be tailored to the student's interests.

4157.title: Vision Transformers (for Visual Intelligence) (2025)
4157.summary: This project explores Vision Transformers (ViTs) for computer vision, focusing on both theoretical understanding and practical application. It involves studying the mechanics of transformers and ViTs, investigating recent advancements in the field. The project aims to apply ViTs to domains like Autonomous Vehicles/Robotics and Medical Image Analysis, or a student-proposed area. The balance between theory and practice will be determined in consultation with the student. Expected outcomes include a deep understanding of ViTs and their potential in various CV tasks.

4158.title: Visual Creativity / Generative Visual AI / multi-modal foundation models (2025)
4158.summary: This project explores multi-modal foundation models for generative visual AI, focusing on text-to-image, video, and 3D content creation. It investigates architectures like DALL-E 3, Stable Diffusion, Sora, and others. The research aims to understand and apply these technologies, potentially incorporating AI-generated sound and music. Specific applications will be defined collaboratively with the student.

4159.title: Visual Intelligence and accurate geo-referencing of road objects on mobile devices (2025)
4159.summary: This project aims to develop a mobile application leveraging visual intelligence and precise geo-referencing for road object assessment. Utilizing a mobile device's camera and accurate positioning equipment (u-blox with CPos), the app will employ AI models to evaluate and geo-reference road object conditions. Expected outcomes include a functional application for road infrastructure monitoring, with potential applications in HD-map creation, real-time image matching for localization, and data collection for neural rendering. The project is a collaboration between national road authorities, SINTEF, and municipalities.

4160.title: Implementation and Evaluation of Partial Redundancy Elimination
4160.summary: This project focuses on implementing and evaluating partial redundancy elimination (PRE) within the JLM compiler, which utilizes the Regionalized Value State Dependence Graph (RVSDG) intermediate representation. The goal is to add a PRE transformation to JLM and compare its performance against the existing common node elimination. The project involves understanding PRE and global value numbering literature, the RVSDG IR, and the JLM compiler code. The implementation will be done in C++ using the LLVM infrastructure. The expected outcome is a functional PRE pass in JLM and an evaluation of its effectiveness.

4161.title: *NEW*: Attention mechanisms to improve point cloud generation from images of stereo cameras in the marine domain
4161.summary: This project explores improving point cloud generation from stereo camera images in challenging marine environments using attention mechanisms. The research focuses on adapting deep learning techniques, specifically attention mechanisms, to identify features of interest in marine imagery, overcoming the limitations of traditional methods in environments lacking distinct landmarks. The project will use simulated and real-world stereo data, validated through field tests on Fugro's USV. Expected outcomes include a neural network architecture capable of generating accurate point clouds from stereo images in marine settings, enhancing obstacle detection and collision avoidance.

4162.title: *NEW*:  Assess weather and sea conditions from SITAW data
4162.summary: This project aims to develop weather assessment methods using onboard sensors (cameras, LIDAR, radar, IMU) and weather forecasts to improve the performance of situational awareness systems in adverse conditions. The research will focus on adapting target tracking and sensor fusion algorithms based on weather estimations. The project will primarily use simulated data, supplemented by real-world data collected from Fugro's USV. The expected outcome is an adaptive system that maintains a minimal level of performance in varying weather conditions. Technologies used include machine learning, computer vision, Python, and/or C++.

4163.title: *NEW*:  Target detection and tracking using W-Band radarBackground: While the LIDAR sensor has proven its efficiency for collision avoidance and docking use cases in harbors and inland water areas, its sensitivity to adverse weather conditions such as fog
4163.summary: This project focuses on developing target detection and tracking algorithms for W-band radar to improve situational awareness in marine offshore applications. The research will address the higher noise levels associated with W-band radar by designing algorithms that fuse its data with other sensors like cameras, AIS, and X-band radar. The algorithms will be implemented in Python or C++ and validated through field tests on Fugro's USV. The expected outcome is a robust target detection and tracking system suitable for all-weather conditions.

4164.title: Non-visual interaction for mixed reality environments for children
4164.summary: This project explores non-visual mixed reality interactions for children, aiming to create engaging XR experiences without isolating them from their physical and social surroundings. It will leverage multisensory input (body motion, gestures, positioning, speech) and generative AI to deliver tailored feedback through haptics, audio, and light. The project will involve interaction design experiments and elicitation studies to identify optimal combinations of sensory feedback and adaptive solutions for natural interaction, potentially using "magic-wand" like devices. The goal is to support richer, embodied user experiences for children of mixed abilities in learning, communication, and play.

4165.title: NeRFs in Motion: Learning Dynamic Environment Representations for Autonomous Agents
4165.summary: This project explores adapting Neural Radiance Fields (NeRFs) for dynamic environment representation for autonomous agents, fusing stereo camera, LiDAR, and IMU data. The research aims to develop a real-time NeRF-based system capable of handling moving objects through semantic segmentation and explicit modeling. Evaluation will focus on reconstruction quality, consistency, and usability for tasks like collision avoidance, compared to SLAM-based methods. The expected outcome is a prototype system demonstrated on datasets like KITTI or Waymo, providing insights into trade-offs between fidelity, speed, and computational load.

4166.title: AI as a co-teacher
4166.summary: This project explores using AI, specifically Large Language Models (LLMs), as a co-teacher to assist educators. The research focuses on developing and testing a domain-specific LLM to improve curriculum design, align course content with learning objectives, and aid in assessment and evaluation. The expected outcome is a tool that can ethically assist teachers in their daily routines, enhancing course planning and student outcome analysis. The project requires skills in Machine Learning, Generative AI, LLMs, and Python programming.

4167.title: *NEW*:  Adaptive Motion Planning for Small-Scale Autonomous Ships Using Reinforcement Learning and Model Predictive Control
4167.summary: This project aims to develop an adaptive motion planning system for small autonomous surface vessels (ASVs) using a hybrid Reinforcement Learning (RL) and Model Predictive Control (MPC) framework. The RL agent will generate control sequences based on environmental representations, while MPC will validate and refine these sequences for dynamic feasibility and safety. Expected outcomes include a hybrid planning architecture, analysis of environmental representations, and a simulation-based evaluation benchmarked against existing methods. The project will utilize tools like Python, PyTorch/TensorFlow, and ROS2.

4168.title: RAG for Course Preparation
4168.summary: This project explores Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) using Large Language Models (LLMs) for course preparation. It involves testing state-of-the-art LLMs on educational content, benchmark datasets, and a real-world use case. The student will evaluate the generated responses objectively and subjectively, potentially gathering student feedback through surveys. The project requires Python programming and knowledge of Machine Learning, Generative AI, and LLMs. The expected outcome is an evaluation of RAG's effectiveness in educational settings.

4169.title: *NEW:   SLAM for autonomous docking  (coop. with Zeabuz)
4169.summary: This project develops a robust SLAM system for autonomous maritime vessel docking, addressing the challenges of feature-scarce marine environments. It integrates data from LiDAR, radar, and cameras for precise localization, enhancing GNSS-based navigation and providing a fallback solution. The project involves literature review, implementation of SLAM methods using ROS/ROS2, simulation-based evaluation, and real-world testing on NTNU/Zeabuz platforms. Expected outcomes include improved docking accuracy, dock position estimation, and identification of docking locations, contributing to safer and more efficient autonomous maritime operations.

4170.title: *NEW*: Monocular depth estimation for maritime situational awareness  (coop. with Zeabuz)
4170.summary: This project explores monocular depth estimation for enhanced maritime situational awareness in autonomous vessels, in collaboration with Zeabuz. It involves reviewing and implementing deep learning models to extract depth information from camera images, addressing the limitations of traditional sensors. The project will develop a sensing pipeline, benchmark it against existing sensors like radar and lidar, and integrate it into an autonomy system for collision avoidance. Real-world experiments using NTNU and Zeabuz platforms are expected. The student should have a background in sensor fusion, deep learning, and computer vision.

4171.title: *NEW*:   Enabling deep learning in maritime object tracking  (coop. with Zeabuz)
4171.summary: This project, in collaboration with Zeabuz, focuses on enabling deep learning for maritime object tracking. It aims to develop software for automatic collection of maritime sensor data, using radar-based trackers to trigger targeted high-resolution camera and radar data recording. The collected data will be used to train deep learning-based tracking pipelines, adapting methods from the automotive domain, with a focus on attention-based mechanisms. The expected outcome is a trained and evaluated tracking method suitable for maritime environments, leveraging both radar and camera data.

4172.title: Graphical user interfaces for operating drones for ship inspections
4172.summary: This project focuses on developing user-friendly graphical user interfaces (GUIs) for operating drones in ship inspections, specifically for pre-dismantling assessments. The research involves understanding current ship inspection methods, designing and prototyping GUIs tailored for inexperienced drone operators, and evaluating their effectiveness with end-users. The expected outcome is a GUI prototype that enhances the usability of drones for ship inspections, contributing to improved safety in ship-breaking processes within the SHEREC project.

4173.title: Graphical user interfaces for operating magnetic crawler robots for cutting ship hulls
4173.summary: This project focuses on developing user-friendly graphical user interfaces (GUIs) for operating magnetic crawler robots used in cutting ship hulls, aiming to improve safety in ship dismantling. The research involves understanding current hull-cutting practices, designing and prototyping GUIs, and evaluating their effectiveness with end-users who lack robotics experience. The project is part of the SHEREC project, which aims to improve safety in the ship-breaking process through digitalization and deployment of robots. Expected outcomes include functional GUI prototypes tailored for cutting ship hulls using magnetic crawler robots.

4174.title: Graphical user interfaces for operating mobile robotic arms for cutting ships internally
4174.summary: This project focuses on developing graphical user interfaces (GUIs) for operating mobile robotic arms used in the internal cutting of ships, aiming to improve safety by replacing manual labor. The research involves understanding ship-cutting processes, designing and prototyping user-friendly GUIs, and evaluating their effectiveness with end-users who lack robotics experience. The expected outcome is a GUI that facilitates the safe and efficient operation of robotic arms for ship dismantling, contributing to the SHEREC project's goals of digitalization and robot deployment in ship-breaking.

4176.title: Designing user interfaces for facilitating coordination between on-board and shore-based operators
4176.summary: This project aims to design user interfaces that improve coordination between on-board and shore-based operators to reduce energy consumption in maritime operations. The research will involve understanding current communication practices, prototyping user interface designs, and evaluating their effectiveness in facilitating collaboration. The expected outcome is a user interface that enables better information exchange and decision-making, leading to reduced energy consumption. This project is part of the OpenZero project and will be co-supervised by Dr. Taufik Akbar Sitompul.

4177.title: User interfaces for distributed route planning and oversight for hybrid sail ships
4177.summary: This project focuses on designing user interfaces for distributed route planning and oversight for hybrid sail ships, aiming to optimize routes based on weather forecasting and operational requirements. Key activities include researching factors affecting sail usage, prototyping user interface designs for route planning and oversight, and evaluating prototypes with end-users. The expected outcome is an effective user interface that supports the wider adoption of sail ships by facilitating smart planning and real-time monitoring within the OpenZero project's goal of reducing maritime carbon emissions.

4178.title: Designing user interfaces for remotely operated offshore cranes
4178.summary: This project focuses on designing and evaluating user interfaces (UI) for remotely operated offshore cranes, aiming to improve operator safety. The research involves gaining insights into remote crane operations, prototyping UI designs, and evaluating these prototypes with end-users. The project is part of the OpenRemote project, which develops open-source design systems for remote machinery. Expected outcomes include effective UI designs validated by user feedback, contributing to safer and more efficient remote crane operations.

4179.title: Designing a design system for operating bipedal and quadrupedal robots
4179.summary: This project aims to develop a design system for creating graphical user interfaces (GUIs) to operate bipedal and quadrupedal robots. The project involves reviewing existing robot GUIs, designing and prototyping UI elements, and evaluating their usability. The expected outcome is a documented collection of UI elements, visual guidelines, and design principles that can be used to ensure design consistency and reduce development time for robot operation interfaces. This project is part of the OpenRemote project and will be co-supervised by Dr. Taufik Akbar Sitompul.

4180.title: Reuse Made Easier: Co-Designing a Digital Solution for Increased Furniture Reuse at NTNU
4180.summary: This project explores how a digital solution can improve furniture reuse at NTNU's Gjenbrukstorget, aiming to reduce waste and promote sustainability. Using service design and participatory design, the research will identify barriers and develop a user-friendly digital platform. Methods include interviews, observations, co-design workshops, and prototype testing with staff and students. The expected outcome is a central, accessible digital service that enhances furniture reuse, contributing to a more sustainable university.

4181.title: MIC - Medical Image Computing / Analysis and AI/CV (most organs / most modalities) (2025)
4181.summary: This project focuses on medical image computing using deep learning and computer vision techniques applied to various organs (heart, liver, lungs, etc.) and modalities (CT, MR, ultrasound, digital pathology). The project aims to develop and test models like U-mamba, utilizing MONAI for development. Expected outcomes include advancements in medical image analysis and potential publications, supported by collaboration with MIRA, SINTEF Health, NTNU, and St Olav hospital. Individual or paired work is possible.

4182.title: Autonomous Driving (AD): NAP-lab related projects based on Visual Intelligence (AI/CV)++ (2025)
4182.summary: This project explores various aspects of autonomous driving (AD) using visual intelligence (AI/CV) within the NAP-lab. Key areas include end-to-end AD, sim-to-real gap closure via Neural Rendering, TeleDrive over 5G, HD-maps/Digital Twins using NVIDIA Omniverse, crowdsourcing for map updates, and anonymization of camera data. The research utilizes a KIA e-Niro equipped with NVIDIA DRIVE AGX Orin, multiple sensors, and a drive-by-wire system, along with simulators like CARLA and NVIDIA DRIVE Sim. Expected outcomes involve advancements in AD algorithms, improved simulation fidelity, and practical applications in real-world driving scenarios.

4183.title: High quality interactive digital twins in VR
4183.summary: This project focuses on developing a VR environment for visualizing and interacting with digital twins, in collaboration with the Institute of Cybernetics. The research will explore the creation of high-quality, interactive VR representations of digital twins, using examples such as autonomous aquariums/greenhouses, soil movement experiments, and overload prevention in electric cables. The expected outcome is a functional VR environment that allows users to monitor, control, and interact with real-time data from these digital twins.

4184.title: Agile transformation in organizations
4184.summary: This project explores agile transformation within organizations undergoing digital transformation, contrasting it with traditional "big bang" approaches. It involves a qualitative literature review of agile and digital transformation research, followed by a field study of a real-world case organization using interviews and observations. The expected outcome is new knowledge and recommendations for organizations on effectively using agile principles in their digital transformation initiatives.

4185.title: Combining EEG and motion capture in immersive VR environment (2025)
4185.summary: This project explores combining EEG and HPE-based motion tracking within a VR exergame for enhanced patient feedback in rehabilitation. The research involves synchronizing EEG data, human pose estimation, and VR content using pipelines like NeuroPype or Timeflux via LabStreamingLayer. Expected outcomes include a functional system providing real-time feedback on attention levels, movement intention, and cognitive load, potentially improving rehabilitation outcomes. This project is in collaboration with prof. Marta Molina at the Institutt for teknisk kybernetikk.

4186.title: Sensorimplementering i skipsbransjen og behandling av skipsdata
4186.summary: This project explores sensor implementation in the maritime industry for automated classification and continuous monitoring, addressing data sharing and standardization challenges. It focuses on scaling the VISTA Gateway for diverse data formats and standardizing Maintenance Activity Data (MAD). The research investigates combining various standards and optimizing real-time and batch processing. Expected outcomes include insights into the technical, organizational, and sustainability impacts of sensor-based classification, along with recommendations for data handling and processing in the maritime sector.

4187.title: Chatbots in public sector
4187.summary: This project investigates the use of chatbots in the Norwegian public sector, focusing on citizen interaction with agencies like municipalities and NAV. It involves a literature review and an empirical study to understand how citizens use these chatbots and identify potential issues like exclusion. The research aims to provide empirical knowledge and recommendations for developing and implementing chatbots that better serve the public sector's needs. The project requires qualitative research skills and can be conducted and written in Norwegian or English.

4188.title: Performance study of parallelization techniques for proxy applications in scientific computing
4188.summary: This project investigates parallelization techniques to enhance the performance of proxy applications, which emulate performance bottlenecks in scientific computing. The research will involve experimenting with various parallelization approaches on HPC architectures, applied to a chosen proxy application. The expected outcome is an evaluation of the effectiveness of different parallelization strategies in improving the performance of scientific computing applications.

4189.title: Profiling submissions for AI assisted content
4189.summary: This project aims to develop deep learning models for identifying AI-assisted content and plagiarism in student submissions. The research will involve a literature review to determine optimal models and features for classifying individual writing styles. Attention-based deep learning models will be trained using datasets collected from student writing samples. The expected outcome is a system capable of profiling submissions to distinguish between original work and AI-generated content.

4190.title: Biodiversity monitoring tool
4190.summary: This project proposes a wildlife monitoring tool using deep learning models like Species Net for automatic animal detection, localization, and segmentation. Addressing challenges in wildlife image analysis, such as low-quality images and varying conditions, the tool aims to automate animal labeling on a large scale using camera trap images. The expected outcome is a functional tool that assists researchers and biologists in efficient biodiversity monitoring.

4191.title: Preparing Planslurpen for integration into municipal processes
4191.summary: This project focuses on integrating "Planslurpen," a machine learning-based tool for extracting zoning plan information, into municipal processes. The research will involve collaborating with municipalities and developers to assess needs and improve Planslurpen's functionality. Potential areas of investigation include designing a data infrastructure for seamless integration, developing an AI chatbot, optimizing the Planslurpen API, or enhancing information retrieval and presentation. Expected outcomes include a scalable and interoperable architecture, improved user trust through explainability, and a proof-of-concept implementation of AI-friendly optimizations.

4192.title: Streamlining the municipal reviewal process of zoning plan archives through artificial intelligence
4192.summary: This project explores streamlining municipal zoning plan archive review using AI to improve efficiency for developers and caseworkers. The research will involve literature review, implementation, and testing of existing AI methods on zoning plan archives from Trondheim and Kristiansand municipalities. The project aims to develop and evaluate AI-driven approaches, potentially incorporating explainability techniques to enhance trustworthiness. Expected outcomes include identifying strengths and weaknesses of current methods, proposing new methods, and testing them on diverse datasets.

4193.title: Measuring the Coding Experience
4193.summary: This project investigates the coding experience using biometric sensors (EEG, eye tracking, GSR) to analyze cognitive load and engagement. User tests will be conducted, potentially comparing coding tasks with and without AI assistance. The project involves literature review, experiment design, data collection, and analysis. Expected outcomes include insights into the learning process and the impact of AI tools on coding. Data processing scripts and visualizations may be developed.

4194.title: Counterfactual Explainability for Human Activity Recognition
4194.summary: This project explores counterfactual explainability for human activity recognition (HAR) using time series data from the HARTH dataset. It aims to develop a novel counterfactual generation method that considers temporal coherence and plausibility, leveraging Transformer-based and LSTM models. The research will focus on generating realistic and actionable counterfactuals to improve recognition accuracy and interpretability. Expected outcomes include a new counterfactual generation technique, exploration of representation methods, and benchmarking against state-of-the-art approaches.

4195.title: [NorwAI/NAIL] Symbolic AI for enhancing reasoning and trustworthiness of GPTs
4195.summary: This project explores enhancing GPT models' reasoning and trustworthiness using symbolic AI, such as case-based reasoning. The goal is to reduce hallucinations and opaqueness in GPTs by integrating symbolic methods. The project involves implementing a prototype that combines GPT with a symbolic AI system, potentially through fine-tuning GPT with knowledge graphs or using a CBR system for retrieval-augmented generation. Expected outcomes include a validated prototype and improved GPT performance on complex reasoning tasks. Technologies include Python, deep learning frameworks, and data processing libraries.

4196.title: Parallel Approximate Similarity Join in Vector Databases
4196.summary: This project explores scalable approximate similarity join (ASJ) in vector databases using parallelization techniques on GPUs or distributed systems like Spark. The research focuses on algorithmic and indexing aspects, leveraging pre-trained embeddings. The project involves studying existing ASJ solutions, developing or extending them for parallel execution, and implementing/evaluating the solutions on large datasets. Strong C++ programming skills are required. The expected outcome is an efficient and scalable ASJ implementation for high-dimensional vector data.

4197.title: Visualizing Sepsis Risk Using Clinical Phenotypes
4197.summary: This project aims to develop a visual risk prototype for sepsis detection using clinical phenotypes from St. Olavs Hospital medical records. The research will focus on visualizing patient similarity based on signs, symptoms, conditions, and in-hospital events to aid clinicians in identifying patients at risk for sepsis. The expected outcome is a prototype that helps in understanding patient groups and improving sepsis treatment strategies.

4198.title: Identifying Sepsis Clinical Phenotypes Using Structured and Textual Data
4198.summary: This project aims to identify distinct sepsis clinical phenotypes using structured and textual data from St. Olavs Hospital medical records. The research will analyze patient signs, symptoms, conditions, and in-hospital events to categorize different sepsis patient groups. The expected outcome is a refined understanding of sepsis patient heterogeneity, contributing to improved risk identification and treatment strategies.

4199.title: The value of AI
4199.summary: This master's project investigates the value of AI for society, organizations, and individuals through a systematic literature review and empirical field study. It aims to create a framework for evaluating AI benefits, drawing from information systems, computer-supported cooperative work, and human-computer interaction literature. The project will generate new empirical knowledge through qualitative research, focusing on a specific field to be determined collaboratively. Expected outcomes include a comprehensive understanding of AI's value and practical insights from the field study.

4200.title: Generative AI and artistic creation
4200.summary: This project investigates the impact of generative AI on artistic creation, audience engagement, and the art market. It will explore how AI disrupts traditional artistic processes while also enabling new creative opportunities. The project involves a literature review, design and implementation of an empirical study potentially focused on developing AI tools, and data analysis to assess the transformative effects of AI in art. Expected outcomes include insights into the evolving role of AI in art and its implications for artists and audiences.

4201.title: Multimodal Plant Health Monitoring
4201.summary: This project aims to develop a multimodal plant health monitoring system by integrating IoT-enabled soil sensor data with UAV imagery (RGB, Multispectral). The research will focus on accurately detecting, classifying, and predicting plant health by combining below-ground soil properties with above-ground visual symptoms. The project will utilize image processing, deep learning, and Python programming to analyze temporal soil sensor data (moisture, pH, nutrients) and UAV images. Expected outcomes include improved accuracy in plant health assessments, actionable insights for resource optimization, and enhanced early intervention strategies for sustainable agriculture.
